description:
Calling ALL Teriyaki and Bento NOMsters!

If teriyaki, katsu, tempura, donburi, udon, and bento are your thing, then Fujiyama is right up your alley. 

Fujiyama is a no-frills, neighborhood Japanese restaurant where you can leave with your triple muffin top avalanching over your belly-induced stretched belt (Thank goodness for Spanx) for less than $15 with tip. Super cheap for Japanese food but don't expect top-notch quality. 

There seems to be a debate of whether Fujiyama is Japanese or Korean owned. Here's the answer to your question: http://www.manta.com/g/mm8gdqd/seikko-matzuyama If you can't differentiate "Kim" from "Yamaguchi"....Houston we have a problem.

Service is friendly BUT slow so the complimentary miso soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=Eu8nqhu5lCJIvNXLW-3o8Q) and salad with the sinfully good creamy miso-like dressing (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=6FKaBJ1AQ6T_BlxIb2fJ8w) really holds you down until you get your food. 

My friend who's a regular recommended that we start with the Soft-Shell Crab ($5.95) with a panko-crust giving it more of a crunch with a nice granular texture (compared to tempura batter). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?selected=iFXjjTF_YBdktWmnNo2qKw The accompanying vinegar sauce reminded me of the Filipino sinimak (spiced vinegar) which helped cut through some of the richness. He also recommended the highly touted Beef Amiyaki ($11.95) which is like a thicker version of the Korean Kalbi; nicely charred and succulently tender with a mouth-watering savory sweet marinade. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=oT8xt_TzzTsl-lYrLaT_MA

Everything was all good in the hood until I got my Sashimi Combo (16 pieces - $13.95). Except for the sake (salmon), the kampachi (amberjack), hamachi (yellow tail) and maguro (tuna) was fishy, borderline rancid with a mushy and stringy texture. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=n7jVoBhbxXzz-DQIE42USw For the price, I can't really complain much especially if it didn't send me running to the porcelain throne. 

NOM on the Beef Amiyaki.

NOM on anything fried. 

NO NOM on anything raw. 

OTHER NOTES:
*5 minute wait = 20 minute wait
*5 tables and 4 booths
*Nothing is over $15
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I am growing old w/ this restaurant. Been coming here since my husband & I were still dating back in the 90s then now with our teenager daughter might be taking her future BF! LOL! 

Thank u Sieko, Ester & the rest of the staff! Kudos & more power to Fujiyama!
author: Myla T.

description:
Cheap, good sushi. For the price, this place delivers.

As far as reservations/list sign-up, we got totally screwed by calling and making reservations (they add your name to the list). When arrived 5 minutes ahead of our 'reservation', two parties arrived after us, both of them seated before us. We ended up waiting 45 minutes AFTER our 'reservation time'.

Major lack of effort to even try and seat us near the time we called in for. Pathetic customer service, decent cheap sushi.
author: Ninja R.

description:
Definitely a locals' spot... 

When I used to live in the sunset, wayyy years ago...I'd come here a lot.  I remember having my first salmon nigiri, my first smoked salmon nigiri, my first tuna nigiri, my first tamago nigiri... in fact, this was the place where I learned how to say "nigiri" correctly from the petite, short-haired, soft-spoken, sweet Japanese lady whom I'd see regularly every night I frequented this joint. 

Nowadays... while my palate has learned to advance a bit more and I've ventured to plenty of other sushi restos around the city, I've come to accept that Fujiyama-ya may not be the best resto for stellar sushi, but for the most part, the reason why they've stayed in business for this many years are the affordable prices offered; decent, fresh quality, but not perfect slices; simple, tasty food, but not over the top creative; all the while catering to the locals' liking.  And since I've got somewhat of a kismet relationship with this spot + the sweet lady who serves me my food, I'll continue to frequent them just so I can keep them in business!

THINGS TO EAT:  Beef Amiyaki, Tamago (house-made and still one of the best in the city!), any sashimi dinners, the house salad (comes with bomb salad dressing!), and Pork Katsu (this where I fell in love with pork katsu too).

CONVENIENCE: **** [Located on Noriega St., close to 19th Ave, in the middle of block, parking can be a gamble based on the night of visit.]
AMBIANCE: *** [Not the cleanest, tiny flies swarmed while I ate, but small & cozy inside, accommodates large-ish parties.]
SERVICE: *** [Saw one server sneeze and never wash hands.  I stayed vigilant and watched her only touch the edge of our plates.  Other than that, service is always efficient & served with a smile!]
PRICE: $$ [I ate like a king for $20!  Beef teriyaki, hamachi sashimi, uni nigiri, kappa maki, tamago nigiri, house salad, miso soup, some of my friend's beef amiyaki & we shared a large sake. Yes, I came hungry!!!]
OVERALL: ***/* [3 1/2-stars... rounded up!  For staying an affordable sushi eat & for the memories! *heart*]

Nuff said.

[#65 of 100 YELP CHALLENGE 2013]
author: Lily Y.

description:
I wouldn't go there if it wasn't for yelp's review of course since I was around the area. I filtered for the closest distance. 

The sushi didn't seem too fresh...
I ordered a piece of Uni sushi that tasted as though its been left out in the open for awhile.

The toro sushi was basically a piece of tuna sushi, not tuna belly. 
Unless this tuna has been working out its belly! 

I don't think they even tried putting an effort in making the Unagi don tasty. I mean... how can you screw that up?!
The sauce was worst than ones you can get in Japanese supermarkets.
It tasted like goo. 

Salmon sushi tasted like dried fish.
hmmm
They also forgot our 49er roll we ordered..

Surprisingly I didn't get a stomach ache after the meal! 
So 2 stars for that! 

There are definitely better Japanese restaurants in the neighborhood.
Unless you're really lazy and you live on the same block, i'd recommend you to go else where for the money's worth.
author: Alui L.

description: I had the mixed sashimi dinner plate. Others in our party had the special bento box & the amiyaki beef/chicken. Dinner was good & I would go back. We had a party of 15, so lucky we got there early, bout 5 pm.
author: Rowland W.

description: Good food at a reasonable price. The beef amiyaki is the shining star on the menu. It gets crowded though so expect to wait.
author: Montgomery G.

description: What a great place.  Small, bustling, good energy, good food and a happy crowd.  We came here for the first time - thanks to Yelp - and really liked it.  I had sushi, the bf had a chicken and beef teriyaki.  There was so much food that most of his dish was lunch the next day.  The place was packed with people waiting the whole time we were there, but it turned over quickly enough that I don't think anyone waited too long aka San Francisco long.  We'll be back!
author: w r.

description: My favorite place to go whenever I'm wanting a good affordable Japanese dinner! Of course the sushi and sashimi isn't going to be of the highest quality because of the price but I still rather go here because some places around the city have the same quality for a higher price. I usually would get the Chirashi dinner which comes with a lot of assortment of different fishes. Or I would just get a bunch of rolls because it's hella cheap. The combos and the bento dinner is hella worth it because it comes with gyoza, sashimi, an entree, tempura, miso soup, and salad for just about $15! The waitress here is super sweet and very accommodating. Come before the dinner rush so you don't have to wait as long because the restaurant is small.
author: Korina D.

description:
Love the beef amiyaki! 
The place is small so expect to wait a little.
The decorations inside the store is pretty and very japanese.
The service was good too.
Everything on the menu looks delicious. 
Def coming back! 
My friend had sashimi, and said the portions and freshness is better than other japanese restaurants!
author: Sandy W.

description:
AMAZING PLACE.

Good quality. Low price. Place is a little small and service can actually be terrible during peak times.

Give this place a try, but not during peak times. I promise you will not be disappointed.
author: Chris C.

description:
When I do responsible adult things like get my car serviced, I find little ways to reward myself. (When I file my taxes, it's obviously champagne time. When I refill my Clipper Card on time, I also buy those nail polishes. When I get my car serviced, I treat myself to a sushi dinner). Luckily, the Sunset 76 is conveniently located next to Fujiyama-Ya, so when I discover I have an hour until my car-bits are fully shined, I head directly over to fulfill my sushi-reward. 

I walk into the restaurant, all adult-like, and proceed to get a table, "For one, please," with pride. I confidently ordered a sashimi combo complete with sake sashimi, salad, miso and beer, and I continue to eat and reward the all-growed up lady who is getting her car finally attended to. The sashimi wasn't the best I've had, but it was tasty and appetizingly presented. The salad and miso were perfectly yummy and satisfying. While I chomped the whole pile, the ginger was the pink kind (I prefer the yellow kind. I should probably discover what the difference is). I ordered a beer as well, which came with an adorably small glass -- like the kind I would drink cranberry juice out of at grandma's house -- which was strangely satisfying. 

Speaking of adorable, the service was in the same category. The waitress (maybe the owner), was perfectly attentive and sort of understood that I was having a triumphant personal reward-meal. She even hopped to it when Sunset 76 called 25 minutes early to tell me that my car was already done. I got the check and retrieved ye olde vehicle on time.  

Thanks for lovely meal! Another reason why the Sunset is the best kept secret nest of the city.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
I've been coming here to this spot for a very long time. It's like a ma and pa shop, japanese style. It's very home-y and we are always greeted warmly by Esther. It does get crowded on the weekends, so if you're trying to go and have a huge group, you can call and try to make a reservation.

The items to definitely try are Beef Amiyaki, Beef Yakiniku, Salmon Teriyaki, Katsudon, and Sukiyaki. I normally order the combo with Sukiyaki and Sashimi or the Beef Yakiniku. Also, their salads that come with the entrees are my favorite. They kind of drench it in their dressing, but it is still so darn good. They have good portions and the prices are reasonable. 

If you're in the Sunset, come check it out! Then you can always top off the night with some Golden Island :)
author: Ashley L.

description: Went on Valentine's Day dinner with group of friends! Wasn't too long to be seated for a day like that! However, we waited long time for food. They gave us one bowl of white rice and then waited another 30 minus for the sushi roll to come! My friend's 2 yrs old son did not want plain white rice anymore! Our teapot was empty for a long while before I can get the waitress to fill! Food wasn't not bad! Tempura chicken wing was good and juicy! Restroom was not very clean! Roll of toilet paper was on the wet, greasy floor! Luckily, I have my own pack of tissue paper!
author: Katherine L.

description:
The sushi is okay here but I'd rather spend my money at my fave sushi bars. The number one thing to get here is the beef amiyaki that comes on a sizzling plate. It's delicious and smells amazing.

Babe and I ordered the beef amiyaki and an assortment of sushi rolls, tuna maki, and some handrolls. None of the sushi rolls really called out to me but the beef amiyaki is well worth trying.

Service is nice but we were forgotten among the large party. Dining area is also very small so it'll be hard to get a seat if they're busy.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Absolutely fantastic sushi!!!!!! Perfect portions. Udon soup noodle comes out with large sides of tempura shrimp and veggies. Service is so damn quick. You sit you order and your food is ready before you can even think to Ask about it. I'd highly recommend this place. They are about their business. Customer service was good. Sushi quality was great. Def def satisfied my tastebuds before my red eye flight. And this is just a walks away from the 16th Ave steps
author: Minjee Y.

description:
love this place. you will get your money's worth of food. we get to-go a lot. Full menu can be found online. i like their teriyaki unagi but it is better with dine-in for this dish since it comes in a hot plate and sizzling. goes great with their rice. their uni is decently priced too. 

I tend to get their chirashi 12 piece bowl. you get choice of 2 types of sashimi. it's tuna and yellowtail for me. Delicious! little bits of tamago in the rice. nice touch! I love the rice. I don't often say that but theirs I can eat all of it. free miso soup and salad with meal. free green tea too for dine-in. with to-go, comes with salad only. 

nice local joint. Family run place which I like to support.
author: Jules L.

description:
My absolute favorite mom and pop shop for Japanese food! Cheap and tasty food accompanied by quality service. Below reviews can attest to how sweet Ester really is :) 

Upon arriving, I usually call in ahead to make a reservation since parties are seated based on the time they arrive. Party size is usually irrelevant so even if a table for six becomes available, they will sit a party of two. Expect to wait anywhere between 15 minutes to an hour, so get there early! There's a bar next door so I usually will sip on a few drinks while I wait for my table to open. For appetizers, I usually stick with getting a few orders of the spicy scallop roll and California roll. Spicy scallop is a pretty basic roll with raw scallops topped with a spicy sauce. Simple but still very good. I highly recommend it! Even my friend who doesn't like raw seafood loved it. Beware though, the sauce can be kinda spicy after you've consumed a couple pieces. I usually just power through though cause it's sooooo good! For my entree, Combo K ($12.95) is a no brainer. It comes with a huge serving of unagi (served on a sizzling plate) and sashimi. You can choose between salmon, tuna and hamachi. Can't go wrong with the salmon or hamachi. Granted it's not the best quality, it's still tasty and gets the job done. All combos also come with free miso soup, rice and salad. I absolutely love the salad - I mean, I know it's a very basic American salad but the dressing is super creamy. Yum!

Only downside is that service can be a little slow, but only because the restaurant is always packed. You can tell that the staff tries their best to attend to every table and I appreciate the effort. So for anyone looking for cheap and tasty Japanese food, definitely give this place a try. You won't regret it!
author: Melissa T.

description: Had reservations for 9:30 pm on a Saturday night, running late so we moved it to 9:40 drove all the way from Daly City just to say that they were closed when it was 9:40 & all the servers were just eating dinner together at a table. Might have been good, business is business.
author: Briana C.

description: Reasonable priced. Tasty food with generous portions. Staff are very friendly and attentive especially Esther, sweet lady. My go to place for local "hole in the wall" Japanese food.
author: Cee B.

description: Food was amazing. I had the sukiyaki with the sashimi for only 11.95!! The food came out quick and service was decent. The interior was a cute and comforting place, great for a night out to eat!
author: Sawlat T.

description:
This place is always packed, and I can see why now that I've been there. My man and I beat the Sunday dinner rush and snuck into a little booth. We were quickly greeted with menus and tea. I was jonesin' for chicken Katsu, he wanted sashimi. We looked over the menu and I saw chicken Kara Age. The last time I had Kara Age it was no bueno - too small of pieces, the breading was very thick, just all bad basically. But I thought I'd give it another try and I was very happy with it. Light and crispy and lots of it, my boyfriend and I sprinkled lemon juice over it and shared. 

He got Chirashi shushi whcih was also very good. The tuna was my favorite, and I also liked the yellowtail (I think). Our meals also came with rice and salad, but the salad was waaay over-dressed, it was like salad soup. Nevertheless, a good experience. Our waitress could have been more attentive, but mostly good service, cute, cozy atmosphere. I noticed a lot of people ordering to go, which I wish we had done - not to say the service/atmosphere was terrible, it's just very small inside.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I've been coming here for over twenty years.. Get the Beef Amiyaki or if you don't eat beef you can get a Chicken Amiyaki.. 

This is a well known neighborhood restaurant it's been here for a while. 

Sushi is good. Never a bad thing. Some places won't tell you if it's fresh or not but this place will..
author: Kiel V.

description:
I couldn't believe the prices at this place! I went straight for their 'special rolls' expecting to see a price range of $12-14 like every other Japanese restaurant but instead they were each $8ishh! Absolutely amazing. 

I came with four friends to do saki bombs. We skipped the whole banging the table part since it was early evening and there were families but our waitress was really cool and didn't seem to mind bringing us the necessary cups. 

My boyfriend and I got a crunchy roll, dragon roll, tuna lover, two miso soups, a large Sapporo and a large saki for $38 bucks (that's without tip) which I thought was a pretty good deal considering we usually spend $50+ anywhere else. 

The service was excellent. Once out party arrived she quickly took our order and all of our food came out about the same time. 

We live close by and plan on making this out #1 sushi spot! I have no complaints for my visit yesterday.
author: Erica L.

description:
Went here on a whim while on noriega. Notice this place whenever I passed by but never went in. Glad I gave it a shot.

Was greeted by very pleasant waitress who let us in despite arriving a few minutes before opening. We received complimentary salad and tea which was delightful considering the heat outside. Ordered Tempura donburi and my friend ordered katsu donburi. I received plenty of tempura pieces while my friend got plenty of katsu pork over his rice. 

Servings were plentiful and priced just right. Will come again.
author: Jude N.

description:
I love love love this place!! I came here for years and still ordering the same dishes. 

Amiyaki Beef and 49ers, Philadelphia roll and Uni. 

I have tried the 49ers for so many places and I still find that this place has the best ingredients!!!
author: Elsa Mandy G.

description: One of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city! Either come right when they open or reserve ahead of time because they get packed quickly.
author: Kathleen S.

description: Go to sushi spot. They have rolls that are super cheap and also really delicious, my favorites are the yellowtail roll and spicy scallop roll. Their beef amiyaki is also really good, and I usually get an uni nigiri too. Super reasonable prices for good quality sushi.
author: Sean W.

description:
I like this place a lot, and the parking is pretty easy too. I would probably say it's closer to 3.5 stars (if I could give half a star), only because it's a bit small, the quality though affordable isn't superbly amazing or fancy, but it definitely has two things about it that keep me coming back.

1) Beef amiyaki! Whenever this comes out on the hotplate, the smell and the succulent look of the meat has me drooling and waiting impatiently to dig in. It tastes exactly like it looks: delicious.
2) Affordable selection of sashimi! I love sashimi, especially salmon, and I feel like I can get my meat fix and my sashimi fix here in one sitting without spending a fortune.

I can't remember other dishes, but this place also offers some set course meals (the little bento boxes) that are a pretty good deal since it comes with a variety of items plus soup and salad. This place can get crowded sometimes so don't come in a big group, but it's worth a 20 min wait if you're in the area and have less than 4 people with you.
author: Nancy W.

description: 21 years and counting we've been coming here. On our way tonight. Hopefully we'll beat the crowds. We  Fuji!  Hope you do too, just on a different night.
author: Us And J.

description: This is an amazing restaurant! With a small location it feels cozy and warm! Lucky we came at the right time so we were sat down immediately. The service was great and very fast! A very good place, it was worth my review!!
author: Allison B.

description:
Pretty good place if you can stand the wait (each step of the way can take while - getting seated, ordering, waiting for food).  But we had a great time here for Mother's Day dinner. 

The Beef Amiyaki was really yummy (trusty Yelp reviews) and I also enjoyed my Spicy Chicken. Lots of quantity and good quality for the price, I can see why it's a local favorite.
author: Philip L.

description:
I came here twice in about a week. It's a nice gem that is close to home. Plus it's very affordable. However, do not come here if you expect something quick because it is by far a quick meal. For instance, it took my friend and I 50 minutes to be seated, served, eat, and pay our check. You should know we're not slow eaters too. 
Also, it's a small place so don't plan your party dinner here if you expect to bring more than 3 people with you. 

The first time I came:
Shashimi plate comes with tuna, salmon, hamchi, and another pink-ish white fish, a few of the pieces did taste a bit weird.  

Rainbow roll consisted of 3 very similar color. The presentation was not great. The sushi tasted alright. It did fall apart fairly quick. 

I also had the Salmon Roll and Spicy Tuna Roll -- just know sushi is only ok. Do not expect anything spectacular. The rice is nicely vinegar-ed. And that it does fall apart fairly quickly. Many of the rolls is a "California" roll inside. The rolls range from $4-9. 

The 2nd time I came in at 8 and was seated at 8:10 and left at 9pm. 
I had the Beef Amiyaki ($12). This piece of USDA approved slab arrives on a sizzling iron platter. The meat was tastey, tender, and flavorful in 75% of the area. It also contained a lot of fat chunks which weren't hard to slice off. I also got rice, salad, and miso soup. I wish the salad was less watery because it made the salad taste very off. 

My friend had the chicken katsu ($9) - it's evenly battered, not overly done. Also, the chicken is moist which is a plus! 

I would come here again. I'd recommend coming here in small groups. Just set aside about a hour for your meal and you will leave with a fully belly.
author: Jess W.

description: A little whole in the wall sushi place in the sunset neighborhood. Food are decent, services are great and fast. We had 10 piece sashimi, seafood udon, one salmon skin hand roll and a bottle of sake. Total was only 28 after taxes. A cheap, fast and friendly place for Japanese food in the sunset. They cook and the owner is actually Japanese.  Do expect some wait around dinner time.
author: Jade P.

description: The husband and I have been loyal customers here since we were dating (bf to fiancé to husband) 2006 to be exact. The food is very consistent. If you are looking for a japanese place that serves inexpensive  sushi rolls/ makis, bento boxes,sukiyaki/amiyaki place.. Come here! The nigiris and sashimi are a hit or miss here! The service here can be slow but that's normal for a busy restaurant with one/two servers. If you want impeccable service pay for it at Gary Danko.
author: Estella L.

description:
Make sure you are in the first seating if you go on the weekends otherwise you will be waiting a long time for your dinner.  Two people work the front of the house, older woman takes the orders while the younger waitress brings food, drinks, and clears tables.  Need another person to take orders.

The fish is fresh and inexpensive compared to other restaurants.  Did not have any cooked food...glad as it appeared to take longer to make.  The restaurant seems to concentrate on take out.  Saw two tables leave frustrated at the wait.  One table changed their order to take out to speed up the process.
author: Scott L.

description: Small place and there's always a wait but it's affordable and good sushi! I always get the beef amiyaki or the dinner combo with a couple of rolls and nigri. Definitely worth coming here!
author: Joyce C.

description:
I like this place. I actually like cheap sushi (like Kiki's) so when I saw the price list of about half their sushi I was stoked. What this has place that Kitaro and Kiki's don't quite have is a nicer look and atmosphere. There's even a little tiny separate area behind those little wood/paper dividers. Also while I can eat here cheap, I can also get one of the cool fancier rolls (like the Lion King Roll or Cherry Blossom role) for around 10 bucks. So a budget sushi buyer like me can roll in and get 3 rolls for about $4 a piece on the cheaper side, and then get one badass roll and a salad and be out the door for around 25$. Not too bad.

p.s. they give a free small ice cream at the end most times (Green Tea or Black Sesame) that's pretty bomb.
author: Josh H.

description: Nice and friendly staff with large portions of tasty Japanese dishes. I won't call the prices cheap to demote the place ..but it's very affordable! Wish it was open for lunch...
author: JP S.

description:
It feels like a family-styled Japanese restaurant where the prices aren't absurd. The place has a homey feel to it. 

CHICKEN TERIYAKI + TEMPURA COMBO ($10.95)
Chicken was good, nothing mindblowing. Tempura portions were more than I expected. There's 3 pieces of shrimp, 1 piece of salmon (very good!), 1 scallop, 1 zucchini, 1 broccoli, and 2/3 sweet potatoes/yam. 

BEEF AMIYAKI ($11.95)
This is made with rib eye steak. It came out on an iron skillet and was quite good! You can put a bed of rice on top to soak in the beef flavors and have the meat rest on top so it doesn't overcook. 

Both dinner entrees came with miso soup, salad, and rice. We were given an entire rice pot during my most recent visit too - how nice!

If you're looking for good Japanese food at a good price, Fujiyama-Ya is the place to go.
author: Sandy T.

description: Great  prices, super friendly service and good food! Really small location not very suitable for large parties. The wait also tends to be long due to limited seating.
author: Carmen W.

description: A group of friends came here last night (9 of us) and we were there around 5pm but already a line of people waiting outside for tables.  Glad we have reservations made in advance, the food came quickly but the same time they expect you to eat fast and leave fast!  Without asking for the bill, they automatically give us the bill! I am not very happy with that esp this is a group of friends I haven't seen for awhile.  Over all else, the food is delicious which I agreed.  The price is cheap (comparing to most Japanese restaurants).  We ordered all the fish dish, and sushi (cooked & raw).  Bottom Line - if you are with one or two friends, come to this restaurant is ok but with a group of friends, better try somewhere else!  We continue our gathering across the street the Chinese dessert place which was a lot of people too, but they don't tell us to go like this restaurant.  With this being said, I only give this restaurant 3 stars - Okay only!
author: Kitty L.

description: Soooo good!! The sukiyaki is the best item on the menu. Especially if you order the combo with the sashimi. $12. Bam! The sukiyaki has a lot of flavor. Almost as good as the recently closed Hisago. You will have to wait a bit for your food because there is a small staff but it is totally worth the wait.
author: Patricia I.

description:
The only positive thing I can say is that the prices are low - you truly get what you pay for, in this case.

Service was awful, and the food was pretty unpleasant to eat. The sushi did not taste very fresh - kind of like the same-day-preparation sushi you buy from a grocery store. It even had the cheesy fake grass garnish.

Not worth your time or money.
author: Jade M.

description: Definitely worth coming here. Like almost everyone else is saying, the beef amiyaki is the best item they have on the menu. The rolls aren't bad either. The restaurant is pretty small and you should expect a wait, especially if you're coming on the weekends BUT the wait is totally worth it.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Fujiyama-Ya is my new go-to sushi restaurant!  I love that it's a cute little neighborhood spot, with decent sushi and entrees. The fish is always fresh, and good value for when you need that weekday sushi fix. The rolls are cheap, around $10. My boyfriend and I always seem to get the Rainbow Roll.

I love the Oyako-don, which is chicken, onions and eggs over rice. This is the PERFECT dish for when it's cold or raining outside, and you just want something to warm and fill your stomach up. And it's less than $8!  Such a deal! 

Tempura Donburi is also great, includes shrimp, veggies and fish. This one is also under $8 I think. 

Only downsides about this place are that:

1) If you show up on the later side, like 7:30pm or later, then you might have to wait for a seat. This is because the restaurant is so small that it fills up, even on weekdays!  

2) Not open for lunch. If it were open for lunch, I'd be coming here way more often!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: A BUDGET friendly gem WITH GOOD, not great food. Try the Beef Amiyaki (at $13.95 - the most expensive thing on the menu) for a good ribeye. Sashimi combo (16 pieces at $13.95) and and mixed tempura ($5.45) and seafood Nabeyaki ($9.95) are also good.
author: Scott S.

description:
A cute little restaurant that is run by this little old lady. It feels like you're at home.
When I order food here, I feel like it's made with a little bit of love. 
Although the quality is not superior, you definitely get what you're paying for. 
I definitely would recommend this place when you're trying to find a place to satisfy a Japanese food craving with a few friends.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Solid. solid solid solid. 

I love this place! It's convenient and Ester's awesome! I'm a bit bias though because I am always craving this place... so much so my friends already know what I will choose we can't decide what to eat. You definitely get what you pay for and then some...! Quality wise, it's better than most $$$ priced Japanese restaurants.

I can go on for days. Honestly, their cooking is very simple, but it just gives you that satisfaction and a happy tummy...so don't go in with too much expectations. Some people would beg to differ, but i don't care! 

Katsu donburi. Feel like something sweet, but savory? This is the perfect dish. It's VERY simple, don't get me wrong just tonkatsu with some grilled onions, eggs, mushrooms over rice, and a light sauce over to top it off. It's yummy and was the first thing I ever ordered here! It's less than 10 bucks, too!

Combo K: Sashimi and Unagi Teriyaki set. If you don't ask, the sashimi they'll give you is Tuna, but upon request you can get salmon... or I think Hamachi is even a choice! I'm a salmon sashimi lovaaaaaa so, I only get that and it's comparable to the fresh catches my uncle gets. 

I enjoy this place, too because if you just can't decide for the day, they now allow you to make a combo of two items yourself.... happy choosing! I usually end up getting chicken karage with salmon sashimi =D. Their Chicken Karage is (insert thumb emoticon here... then a VERY excited and happy face!) Fries to perfection and it's not just bites of batter... like many other restaurants would do. There are chunks of chicken with each bite... ANDD it's dark meat, too!!!!!!! 

They are known for their amiyakis. Both chicken and beef teriyaki are tasty and you can never go wrong. 

Sushi's solid, no particular favorite roll so meh! But their nigiri's are for a good price and they always look good when I see it! 

Salad and Miso Soup might be another favorite about this place, too... haha I can just eat that and be content. 

FYI there's usually a small wait on the weekends, and be ready to come out of the restaurant smelling like the restaurant (that bbq-like smell) so, if you don't prefer to sleep smelling like that, save your hygiene care for after! 

Fujiyamayayayayayayayayayayaya is just the solid back up for dinner.
author: Johanna T.

description:
Went here with my husband last night, ordered sushi and he ordered this beef teriyaki sizzling plate. Both orders were okay. I have had wayyyy better sushi!!! Their crab tasted really bad and had to pick at all my rolls the whole time.

The only thing i loved was the customer service! 

The ONLY REASON I will want to come back here would be because of their service, i like the way the place was being run. Like a small mom and pop restaurant which i love and like to support. I just won't order anything crab related =/
author: Shanitte N.

description:
Apparently reservations don't mean anything here; made reservations at 7 and didn't get seated until half an hour later (not much space inside to wait either).  Also, they don't seem to remember the order of patrons on the waiting list so remember who came before and after you!

Place is very small and cramped but has an authentic ambiance.  Isn't especially clean; our busser wiped leftover crumbs onto the floor.  However, service was quite good despite how crowded the restaurant was, and we were served quickly.

Sushi wasn't especially flavorful, and neither was the donburi.  They seem to do very well with beef though.  Follow other Yelpers' advice and order the beef amiyaki.  Pricing was very reasonable.
author: Matthew W.

description:
I've never met a bowl of udon I didn't love- until I had the tempura udon here. Udon was over cooked to the point of mushiness. Broth tasted like colored water. 
Thankfully, the tempura was pippin hot and crunchy, and service was efficient.
Skip the karaage chicken too. I finished it only coz the udon was inedible.

Pass
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I was back in the Bay Area and was visiting my good friend, SF, who lives over in the Castro.  I picked her up at her place on Lexington and after some thought and discussion, ended up here.  Fujiyama-Ya is a favorite local spot that SF heads to whenever she can.  

It's a traditional japanese affair, a quaint hole in the wall spot, snuggly situated between a noodle shop and bar.  We arrived @ 4:45pm and sure enough, no change to feed the meter.  We walked across the street to Fujiyama-Ya but they didn't open til 5pm.  As we chatted, a guy pulled up and was going into the noodle house.  I asked if he had change for a dollar.  He said no but proceeded to pull 50 cents out of his pocket to give to me... (sigh)  I miss the Bay Area. 8)  Awesome!  I thanked him, only took one quarter  since the restaurant was going to open soon and I could get more change then.  Big mahalo to the local braddah for the aloha! (Pay it forward, always)

As soon as the sign in the window lit up, we went in.  We were the first ones there.  After we were seated, I walked over to the register and asked for change for the meter.  The waitress Seiko, opened the register but there was none.  She grabbed a "meter card' walked with me across the street, put 45 min. on the parking meter.  Did I mention that I miss the Bay Area?  I love San Francisco, thank you Seiko!  Mahalo! (Customer service rating just shot through the roof!)

SF and I ordered the following:
Sushi Combo Plate - (squid; unagi; ebi; tuna)
Unagi-maki
Fujiyama-Ya Roll (house spider-roll)
Saba (nigiri)
Uni (nigiri)
Tuna (nigiri)
Salmon (nigiri)
Sparkling Sake

See uploaded photo - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=xklTT99D64YdmcHvvTRTSQ

The pricing was fair and the sushi good, a bit more rice than I usually see on maki sushi.  The rice was a little bit on the sticky side, the nori(seaweed), seemed a bit tattered too.  The sushi looked okay, not the freshest looking pieces I've ever seen but tasted fine nonetheless.  Another thing that I found interesting was that the nigiri sushi was sold in one piece servings.  I prefer the two piece nigiri option so you can share it if you want.   

One of my tell-tale tests for places is the freshness of the uni(sea urchin; Hawaiian - wana; pronounced VAH-nah)  Which I only order selectively on sushi visits.  After taking note of the freshness, the rice, and seaweed, I looked at the uni hesitatingly...  It was good.  Uni is one of those sushi items that you do not want to eat even if it's slightly old...  I almost completely abandoned uni after my first time, not too fresh.
Note: Uni is for the avid sushi goer, not for the faint of palate especially if you're particular about texture.

We ordered the Ozeki Sparkling Sake, pink bottle, hana-awaka, very nice.  I never had sparkling sake, very tasy and refreshing.  I thought it was a bit pricey($10 for a small bottle).  I went to an Asian market today, saw the same bottle for $6. (So, maybe not too pricey after all...) 
See uploaded photo - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4jXML1vz29FYYUeoPJIs6A?select=tARda4zT9I6ckur7158fJQ

After the amazing parking meter freebie with the help of Seiko, the waitress could've spilt boiling hot tea in my lap...  'But was very thankful she didn't.  The service was awesome!

Around 6:45pm, the little restaurant was packed.  SF and I sat for a bit finishing our sake, talking but didn't stay too much longer since the steady flow of customers wasn't slowing down. (Definitely, a good thing to see)

If I make it back to Fujiyama-Ya, I will have to try their signature dish, beef amiyaki and their homemade green tea ice cream.

- Aloha

Food: 3
Ambiance: 4
Service: 5+
Value: 4
author: Darrell P.

description:
This is an amazing little Japanese restaurant with some of the best sukiyaki and beef teriyaki options. My girlfriend and I live down the street and we often times enjoy eating here, Esther is such a wonderful host and befriends you with her friendliness as they satisfy your taste buds with miso soup, a delicious salad, and offerings of tea and other beverages.
     I highly recommend going here, even if you order take out but I must say it is quite the experience eating at their location. Keep in mind that they get quite busy quickly so it is best to go right around 5-6pm. Enjoy, I know you will!
author: Diego A.

description:
WTF is going on here with these 4-star reviews? Perhaps they're eating something I don't know about? Maybe there's two restaurants, one amazing one and one super-shitty one where the really good one is hidden behind a secret wall or something?!? 

** THIS WAS MY WORST SF FOOD EXPERIENCE AND MY 2nd WORST SUSHI EXPERIENCE IN 20+ YEARS!! **

Service:
- HORRIBLE
- Waited 20mins before anyone even acknowledged our existence after trying to flag someone down TWICE
- They sat another party at our table. Really.
- I had to get up to get forks, plates, etc.
- I had to get up to pay
- I left $0.00 tip
- They never brought soy sauce to the table

Food:
- HORRIBLE
- Second time I've sent sushi back, in my entire life.
- Quail eggs tasted like poison. I spit it out and didn't eat the other one.
- Rice was HARD.. yes, hard.
- Salmon was slimy
- They brought rolls we never ordered
- We sent back the cucumber salad toppe with octopus. It was inedible. 

This is not a joke, I've literally had sushi at buffets that was 10x's better than this stuff. AVOID AVOID AVOID.
author: Johnson M.

description: This is def one of my favorite Japanese restaurants! I wish I could keep Fujiyama-ya as a secret forever! As of late, they've been a lot more busy but I can't really blame the peeps.. It's a great local hole in the wall restaurant, you definitely get a bang for your buck, and friendly service! Go for the beef amiyaki, dinner combos, sashimi, and their salad dressing... yummmmm!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Our new favorite cheap sushi joint! Solid fish and so reasonably priced.

We were so surprised at this joint and thank fellow yelp reviewers to leading us here. We had the sashimi platter ($14 for 16 pieces!), the rock n roll (unagi and avocado), the spicy scallop roll, and the california roll with real crab meat. The sashimi was quite yummy- the salmon especially was buttery, melt-in-your-mouth, and with a ton of flavor.  The maki rolls we ordered were all less than $4 and well sized (not the tiny ones you'd might expect when you order a cucumber-only roll, for example).

We were pleasantly surprised that we got miso soup and a basic salad to begin with. We also ordered the basic cucumber salad with sesame and sweet vinegar that was fantastic at less than $3. Even the beers were great at only $3 for whatever you like. The green tea ice cream was $1.20! I don't even think you can get ice cream at an ice cream shop for that 

Overall, we loved this place. The decor is cute, the food is great (not the best, but really solid), and you really can't beat the price. We can't wait to share this spot with everyone we know.
author: Amy D.

description:
No matter what I do.. now matter how far I move away from SF.. I keep finding myself coming back to Fujiyama-Ya. 

It sounds like the rest of the world has caught on and lines are out the door nowadays. It's hard for us to plan when we'll be in the city, however when we are, this is a definite stop. 

Food is constantly on point. Beef Amiyaki is freakin bomb dot com. The tempura is off the hook. And the miso is oh so delicious. And tea always tops it off. 

I just ate here the other day and I already want more.
author: Deanna G.

description: This is probably the best Japanese restaurant in the neighborhood, perfect service and delicious food. Loved it !!
author: Dilan Ş.

description: My local sushi spot. Always go here for dinner. They are fast and affordable. Open late.
author: Jazlyn L.

description:
Quick Summary: Solid quality food and at a good value.

Came here after an evening photo shoot and was happy with the varied selection.  We had some sushi lovers in the group and non so it was nice to have the additional options.

The sushi was pretty good, nothing spectacular, but it was pretty fresh and with good flavors.  The value for quality is also pretty good.  I really enjoyed the Beef Amiyaki... nice tender beef, and nice and sizzling.  And I dunno what it is but I love Japanese salad dressing.

A nice place to go to get a quick fix on Japanese, and especially nice if you're looking for a variety of options.  I would have gotten a ramen, but it seemed we were gonna be sharing... and I DON'T LIKE SHARING MY RAMEN!

Definitely worth coming back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Quan D.

description:
For San Francisco, this place has pretty decent food for a pretty decent price.  Portions are a bit on the smaller side, so you might want to order a few more rolls.  I think the highlight of my meal was probably the beef amiyaki.  It was really flavorful and tender... and that smell from the sizzling plate will definitely stick on ya for a while.

We waited for such a short period for our table on a Friday night.  I think we lucked out because by the time we left, there was a decent crowd outside.  The restaurant is pretty small too, so expect to wait a bit regardless. 

Overall, I was pretty happy with this place.. There's nothing that WOW'ed me.. but there wasn't anything that would turn me away either...  3.5
author: Cecilia S.

description: I have a hard time with sushi or any sea/Japanese food. This place has me trying every type of roll and dish possible, amazing quality and service! Thank the being/s above for letting me live a minute walk from it!
author: Ernesto L.

description: Delicious food & service (waitresses are sufficient & friendly), especially my 1st time to dine there last week with one of my best friends who recently finished her chemotherapy about two weeks ago. She was really hungry for tempura & salmon teriyaki. We both enjoyed our deluxe combo meals. Excellent food. Well, again tonight we dined there & the food was excellent again. Except this time, the owner/boss of the restaurant practically threw us out of there. I was very disappointed in her abrupt, rude & rushed gestures of "hurry up get out of here" attitude "so other customers are waiting outside - you paid the bill already." She walked to our table 3 times & the 1st time she says, "ready to go?" My mistake was to pay right away when the bill was presented. Not to be so negative since I think the staff who work for her are great servers & are very polite & plus the food was delicious. We barely finished our dinner in about a 1/2 hour & I barely finished my orange slices & drank my tea & water to digest my food. I really felt like I choked on my last bite because of the rudeness of the owner - I felt compelled to write this up. I feel very disrespected; however, I still love the food & I just hope we don't encounter the owner/boss again if I ever decide to dine there. My youngest son has always ordered take out from there. It's a small place, but as I reiterate, the food is good. Sushi & sashimi seem to be fresher than other similar restaurants here in SF. I would have rated it a 5-star, but because of the rudeness we experienced today, I gave it a 4-star. I understand people wait a long time to dine there especially during the peak hours, but there is no need to be rude. The owner did not even thank us for dining there; however, our waitresses did. I guess you can still be a rude owner/entrepreneur to prosper. The woman is very fortunate to have a friendly staff who cook & serve for a decent restaurant.
author: Arlene Z.

description:
I love this restaurant. 

Super cute and it seems like the owners or the waitress at least, is actually Japanese. 

The food is fresh and I love that you can create your own combos. 

As other reviewers have stated, the beef amiyaki is amaazing. 

Well worth the price for the amount of food that you get.

Oh, also the restaurant is kinda small so there may be a wait depending on what time you go. 

Happy eating!
author: Alison N.

description: This restaurant is popular japanese restaurant around the area. I came here many times. The food is always good and the old lady who been working there for a really long time is really nice and friendly. I would recommend this place, just not when they are busy cuz the wait might take a while. The food isn't that pricey. Last time I came with my sister and nephew, our bill was around $54 and I left $20
author: H R M.

description:
Five stars for this restaurant hands down.

I came here with a large group of friends unexpectedly on a Saturday night. We did not call in for reservation or anything but they were as happy as ever to serve us.

I personally ordered my favorite sashimi dinner combo be because this is definitely worth the money! You get 16 pieces of sashimi for $14. Their fish is very fresh as well. I also received complimentary miso soup and salad. I generally do not like salad dressing but this one was amazing!

I would recommend my new favorite, the scallop roll! That thing was amazing.. 6 pieces slightly spicy for just under $4! What a steal!

In the past I have also enjoyed the beef amiyaki. It is basically a USDA rib eye steak on top of a sizzling plate. What a brilliant idea!

The atmosphere in this restaurant is tiny.. Very stuffy and cozy but there's enough room for everyone. 

Although I came here with a large group, the service was great! I will definitely be coming back here soon.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
It's a small place, cozy and warm. Not hard to find street parking nearby.

Sushi rolls were great for the price (I think like $3 for a standard roll, $7 for a fancy roll). Tonkatsu was standard. But my agedashi tofu kinda made me wanna cry -- they were coated with this gummy gelatinous substance, I think whatever batter they put the tofu in to fry, super ew.
author: Vivian H.

description: My favorite place in the sunset for sushi! Affordable and delicious with a wonderful staff of friendly people. What they do they do really well. Love this place
author: Coco T.

description: Fuji Yamaya is the best sushi place I've ever been to they have amazing prices exceptional service and unbeatable food my favorite sushi roll is the spicy tuna roll! Esther the main hostess is amazing and she always brings me joy. I love this place.
author: Jared B.

description:
I yelped for ramen and was disappointed to see that their menu didn't have any ramen. I'm not sure why they appeared in my search, but I ordered the tempura udon instead and while the batter was good, the dipping sauce was a bit sweet for my taste. The veggies were good, but the shrimp didn't taste very fresh. The broth was OK. 
I liked that it was family run and that it was busy with families/couples. I thought it was good for the price, but not delicious. Would I go back or recommend it to anyone? Not really.
author: Susan B.

description:
My family  has been going here since I was born, so we know the owners and workers of this place really well.

First off, this is not going to be your quality sushi place - they're not known for their high quality sashimi, authenticity, or their great environment. This place is definitely more of your neighborhood sushi restaurant when you're craving some "Japanese food." 

In terms of resevations/space, it's definitely a small restaurant, so be prepared to wait if you are larger than a party of 4-5, especially during meal times.

Large Portions! Definitely get your bang for your buck on these combos. A quick tip is that their teriyaki sauce is actually pretty thick (they add a lot of cornstarch to it). I've heard this is the Korean way of making teriyaki sauce - which makes sense since the owner of the store is Korean. Another tip is to try to avoid the Unagi - it's definitely not the store's best thing.

The best thing on the menu is pretty their Chicken or Beef Amiyaki. Think of it as a mixture between Korean and Japanese cuisine - it's marinated meat on a sizzling platter. What could get better? The only thing is that you can't combo it, so that's a bummer.

Overall: Decent price, A-OK food which satisfies the stomach, decent service.
author: Calvin H.

description:
This. place. is. SO. GOOD.

It's so good that whenever my boyfriend visits the city, our dinner choices are either Fujiyama-ya or somewhere else. 90% of the time Fujiyama-ya wins. We decide on our dinner plans for Fujiyama-ya before we decide on what to do during the day until 5pm, which is when the restaurant opens.

My go-to is the sashimi dinner (8 pieces of 2 types of fish). The sashimi is fresh, and the slices are extremely thick. I usually order sake (salmon) and maguro (red tuna), but sometimes I go for hamachi (yellowtail). Ask for ponzu sauce for dipping instead of soy sauce, and you'll be in sashimi heaven.

My boyfriend's go-to is the beef amiyaki. It comes out sizzling and the smell will make your mouth WATER. Each time we come here the pieces of meat are huge, and the whole piece is cooked to perfection.

In addition, we usually order a roll. We are creatures of habit, so we routinely order the Dynamite Roll, which never ceases to satisfy our tastebuds. The roll is pretty big, comes with six pieces. I like how the rice-to-inside ratio is perfect, just the perfect amount of rice, and a LOT of fish inside.

Total for a sashimi dinner + beef amiyaki + roll = about $30, and includes copious amounts of satisfaction and a nearly overstuffed but content tummy.

This place is definitely a local go-to, and the prices are super reasonable. The food is delicious and authentic, and the staff is super friendly. I'll probably be here next weekend.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
So my friend & I were in the mood for Japanese food. We kinda had some criteria for our dinner location = somewhere new, hole in the wall kind of place, not in the downtown area, & parking isn't horrible. I yelped a couple places & Fujiyama-Ya Japanese Restaurant was our pick! :)

We made reservations for 8pm on a Friday night. We arrived about 10min late & there were 4 other people already waiting to be seated. It's a small little place..definitely busy though. We were luckily seated next...BUT had to share a table with another pair of people. It wasn't too bad though since there was an empty seat in between.

Okay, what to order? 

Gyoza - Tasty potstickers. Nothing wow about them, but they were good.

Beef Teriyaki Donburi - Yum! I asked for it to be medium-well.

Pink Salmon Roll - Spicy, but delish! Baked salmon = yummm :) 

Crunchy Roll - Very good as well :) 

We both got a miso soup & shared the salad. 

It was about $32 & something cents all together. Definitely not bad for all the food we got.

Service was good. Very nice employees.

We luckily found parking right away in the residential area. Yay! : )

We were very satisfied & happy we came to try this place :)
author: Jessica A.

description: Came here with my family for dinner, wasn't packed at all when we got there but service was a bit slow. We ordered the tiger and dragon roll along with the chicken katsu,  seafood udon and two hand rolls.  The tiger and spider looked the same from the outside and when we ate it, it was soggy inside. The hand rolls and the udon was pretty good but the chicken was too dry.
author: Ada W.

description: Very nice experience.  Good quality and great prices.  I'm not a big expert on sushi, but my husband is and he thought the fish was very fresh.  We had a couple of rolls and a couple of the cooked dishes.  Everything we had was excellent.  Service was very friendly.   Great little neighborhood place.
author: Greta R.

description:
Old Fashioned location, just down the block from where bashful bull once as.
Cozy sating, homestyle layout

a)Chirashi Combo has egg pieces in it. Not the tamago egg, but actual egg not sure if thats normal. ..(+1)
No random flavors that weren't supposed to be there (+1)

B)Dragon Roll for once wasn't loaded in Unagi sauce where i couldn't taste anything else.
author: Eric C.

description:
I've been here twice, and I haven't been disappointed yet. It can get pretty busy, but luckily I've never had to wait a long time for a table.

You must try the Katsu Donburi because it's not only delicious, but the portions are huge. My friend and I can eat a lot, but we couldn't even finish it even though we shared it. 

Definitely try the Dragon Roll too! I like how they don't serve it with cucumbers here because I usually have to pick it out at other places. :)

The prices are pretty reasonable. You should definitely check it out if you're in the Sunset and are looking for some good simple Japanese food.
author: Kathy L.

description: As good as it gets. Place is small but cozy. The steak is completely worth the wait. When steak comes to you on a hot iron plate, it's a head turner. Oh and their sashimi is good too.
author: Robin L.

description:
Let me start off by saying the staff here are really nice. 

After coming here many times and trying different dishes, the only thing to come back for is the beef ameyaki. Everything else is just okay. 

My sister and I ordered sashimi here one time and it was not that great. We told ourselves that if we came back, we would not order any raw fish, just cooked food. But with our love for sashimi, we came back for the beef ameyaki and ordered a negihama (hamachi and green onion). We thought with such a small amount of raw fish, you can't go wrong but we were wrong. My sister's first bite into the maki roll had a good size bone in it and that grossed us out for the rest of the roll. 

I had ordered an udon here one time and it was not like any other I'd had (not in a good way). It was soooooo soft/cooked that the udon was splitting apart. Picture a hair with a split end and that's what the strands of udon I was eating looked like. I'm not even sure if it's because the udon was too cooked or too old! 

So overall, I would give 4 stars for service, 4 stars for beef ameyaki and 3 stars to the rest of the food - udon, sashimi, tempura, bento, rolls, etc.
author: Carmen C.

description: Entrees taste great! Esp. Their homemade teriyaki sauce. I usually order their Salmon teriyaki and unagi combo dinner and a caterpillar roll. Chicken teriyaki and tempura are good as well. Sushi rolls are a bit small yet tasty, though they are not necessarily their specialty. But would definitely come here if you're looking good dinner entrees!
author: Eric C.

description:
Cheap sushi near the boyfriend's house? Count me in!

I am quite a sushi snob and always compare sushi places to my beloved Satomi (in Fremont). However, this restaurant is so charming because the staff is friendly and attentive that I can't help but give it a good review. Plus the sushi is incredibly cheap for the amount they give you. On average, the rolls are $7 to $8. What a steal! I love getting the Philadelphia roll, pink salmon lover roll, and dragon roll. Though it is not the best sushi, it still satisfies my craving.

Be sure to come early because this place is super small and can get pretty packed after 6:30.
author: Surge C.

description: Went here for a friends Birthday. We waited awhile outside but take into consideration that it was dinner time on a Friday night. The place is super small but very quaint. There are a few servers and they are swift. I ordered sushi and beef teriyaki. Sushi was amazing! Beef teriyaki looked and tasted like it was a microwaveable lean cuisine. I really recommend going there and ordering a variety of sushi. It's perfect to share. Pricing is amazing! I enjoyed the time there but know to never get the meat again. The tea was warm and tasted nice. Hate to be picky but tea pot looked like it needed washed. Everything else was super clean!
author: Andrea R.

description:
This is our family restaurant.  We have been going here for more than 10 years and by far this is the most authentic Japanese food I had ever eaten.  The restaurant is small, but has a family feel to it.  It is not fancy like other high end restaurants.  Esther, the waitress is amazing and she will remember you and your order if you are a regular customer.  The rest of the staff is great as well.  

Great service, great food and a great place to eat with the family.  The food is worth the price.  I recommend the spicy tuna roll.  The best one yet!
author: Rosie D.

description:
Make this your new go-to spot.  I just did.

Probably the lowest prices I have seen in a while, so low that I was concerned for my safety, but everything we ordered was fresh and came in generous portions.

For 4 rolls, 2 bowls of miso soup (had tons of scallions and at least 7 pieces of tofu, at other establishments there will be 2 wimpy scallion pieces floating around and maybe 3 pieces of tofu) and a chicken katsu bento box the bill was about $22.  And this wasn't during some happy hour, all of our food was ordered and priced based off the regular menu!  

Very impressed, some of the highest-quality sushi I've had in a while.  I don't mean to sound 7 years old, but they have a lot of pictures on their menu which is really nice because you know exactly what you're ordering (I am 95% sure these are actual pictures of their food, because they were different from the ones I usually see on sushi menus), can't wait to go back!
author: Megan A.

description:
I would give this place 3.5 stars.  

Let me just say, you shouldn't come here for mind-blowing sushi, but if you are in the area, this place provides decent sushi at a VERY affordable price. 

The miso soup was pretty good, and the dynamite roll I ordered was decent, but wasn't wrapped well and was falling apart.  However, since the price was so cheap, I didn't really seem to care, and continued happily eating my falling-apart roll with no complaints. 

This is a very small place and there was only one waitress/busser/hostess for the whole place, which I assume, is the owner.   

I probably will come back to try the beef amiyaki that everyone on yelp is recommending, or whenever I'm in the mood for something quick, cheap, and satisfying!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Pretty good Japanese restaurant in the Sunset district.

This place is quite popular (would recommend trying to make reservations- however, this place is so small, I find it interesting that they even allow reservations to occur because it's very hard to accommodate so many people in a small space environment).

By far, one of the tasty rolls that I have had was the Pink Salmon roll (cooked salmon with a mayonnaise sauce on top).  The salmon is cooked perfectly and the combination with the sauce makes it very tasty.  The portions of the other dishes are not skimpy either- they are definitely well worth the money and the price.

The waiting staff is quite busy and aren't as attentive as they could be, so one star down there, but overall the service is decent.

If you are dying to try this place, get there early (around when they open for dinner).  People really start to file in around 6:30-7pm and could potentially make your wait much longer.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
My boyfriend and I went on a Thursday night while it was raining.  The place is cutely decorated and pretty small.  The server sat us at a table that seats 6, but that's okay cause it was the last table open.  There was one more couple waiting after us.  I was wondering if she was going to seat them at the same table because some Asian restaurants in sunset do that since the place can get crowded really fast.

My boyfriend and I shared the beef amiyaki which came with a salad and rice bowl.  The 49er roll, spicy tuna roll, and unagi roll.  We got complimentary green tea and miso soup.  It came out to be $28 without tip.  The food was good.  Not mind blowing but good enough.  I have to say that the spicy tuna roll was my favorite roll due to the orange spicy sauce that was on top of it.  I would definitely come here again.
author: Victoria A.

description:
I think I am about to call out some of the whiners up in here.

#1, this place is amazing. The sushi isn't overly CA fancy, but it is always very fresh and WAY tasty.

#2, it is family owned. Know what that means? When it is packed, you have to wait sometimes. If you want fast, crappy service and frivolous pages upon pages of rolls covered in mayo and filled with sub par fish...there is a college bar type sushi place across the street. You probably need the walk, anyway.

I live in the area, and after trying all the sushi joints around us after we moved, this was THE one. We are super nice to the lady who works there. She remembers us, is always pleasant, and never 'forgets' us (as someone claimed she did). I also witness a whole lot of rude San Franciscans in here on busy nights. Getting pissy with her and demanding more sake like she can't speak English...yeah I would probably forget about you, also.

I highly recommend Fujiyama-Ya if you want delicious medium priced sushi in an intimate setting. They are also one of the few places in the city who have scallop rolls on their menu (something I really like).

Be nice to the lady who works here and she will be nice to you!
author: Rylan S.

description: I've been going here since 1999 when I first moved to San Francisco, and even though I've moved to Oakland, I still visit when I'm in the area. The food is great, the prices are crazy low, and the staff remembers me even though I only make it there once a year or so.
author: Kira D.

description: Such a great place.  Very friendly staff, great prices and the beef (as others have mentioned) is heavenly - definitely my favorite!  I come here with my son who lives near by and this is his favorite go-to.  Can't beat the prices so that is a plus.
author: Beth B.

description: Haven't been here in so long! Decided to come here again and surprisingly the food was a lot better than before. We ordered the beef amiyaki and it was tender and flavourful! The uni was sweet and on point! The hamachi was good. The only reason why I took off one star was because the sushi rice was hard and bland. Their prices went up from before but still very cheap compared to most Japanese restaurants!!
author: A L.

description:
Fantastic little restaurant in inner-outer Sunset.  As many others have said, the Beef Amiyaki is excellent.  Sushi is not top grade, but it is good and very well priced.

You may have to wait for a bit to get a table, due to the size, but I have always found the service to be excellent, and the lady I presume to be the owner is always there and very friendly, but not in a put-on, over the top sort of way.

I see that Yelp says "not kid friendly", but I take my little one here (currently 8 months old) quite a bit.  They have a little chair for him that clips on the table and he scarfs down everything they put in front of him.

Cheers
author: Matt W.

description:
I can't belive I haven't written a review on this place yet?

Well this is going to be very simple..

NO ONE makes a better Beef Amiyaki than this place!! It literally comes sizzling on your plate and it's a big enough portion to split.

My hubby and I always get this as well as the Tuna Poki rolls, spicy scallop roll and the Cali roll with real crab. 

I also love the salad dressing here. I'm sorry but I have yet to taste a better creamy miso-mayo salad dressing and they give you a genorous amount too.

I recommend coming here right at opening on weekends, unless you want to wait outside as they are a smaller place with less seating and no waiting area inside. The owners are nice though and the food is always very fresh and reasonably priced.

TIP: After dinner, if you're like me and have to have to dessert, I suggest walking down the block to Golden Island and ordering one of thier desserts.
author: Petra S.

description:
This has become a nice Japanese fav for me. It's a great neighborhood spot.

The prices for the food quality are amazing! Can't get enough! I loved the tuna roll, veggie gyoza, agedashi tofu, and pretty much everything else they serve.

Great for take out and for eating at the restaurant... but beware because it can get very packed on random nights!
author: Carleen W.

description:
I'm not going to lie, it's not the freshest sushi in San Francisco but for the price, it's good. 

We had gone to Okazu Ya (on Taravel) the day before and we still on the sushi craving train so we were Yelping for cheap nearby sushi restaurants. Fujiyama-Ya showed up on our Yelp radar.

At first, I was a bit skeptical of the quality because of the prices, we could not believe that it could be that affordable. At Okazu Ya, we ordered two roll and our bill came out to $24 without tip and at Fujiyama-Ya we ordered 4 rolls and our bill came out to $34. Good and cheap, right?

Caterpillar Roll: it was a bit mushy but I love bbq eel.
49-er Roll: I think this was my favorite roll out of the bunch that we got. I was delicious and I think I went for this one more than the others.
Dynamite Roll: just the right amount of spiciness. I know some places claim they use spicy tuna but it isn't spicy at all.
Rainbow Roll: I think this would be my second choice.

If we are ever craving sushi again, we are definitely coming back here for some more rolls.
author: Mona L.

description:
I remember coming here eons ago, but wandering around decided to come here tonight. Wasn't disappointed.

Good prices, good portions, food is good. Service can be spotty but be patient, the food will make up for it.

We got the special bento with chicken teriyaki, tempura,tuna sashimi and gyoza. The teriyaki was terrific, really done on a flame grill. I hate places that don't really grill it, i.e. don't have grill marks or charring, but Fujiyamaya does it right. The tempura was good and the gyoza was tasty.

We got a seafood udon. It was a tad bland but my wife said it was not bad. 

We got the 16 piece sashimi platter. Big large pieces of sashimi. Had 4X4 pieces of what I like best so that rocked. It includes hamachi, maguro, white tuna, and sake (salmon). 

Only thing I didn't like was sitting in those hard and straight booths. My back was killing me afterwards. Next time I'll ask for the tables with regular chairs.
author: Dom L.

description: I really want to like this restaurant. But, unfortunately, this restaurant has lackluster food, and lackluster service. The last few times I've been here, something strange with the service happened that spoiled the experience. This time, I brought my mother here because she wanted a local restaurant nearby where she lives. We are both Japanese. We ordered the Chicken Teriyaki plate for my mother, and the yakitori appetizers, gyoza appetizers, and 7 piece sashimi for me. The Chicken Plate and yakitori came out in a very timely manner. Both were just ordinary. However, after 30 minutes, the gyoza finally arrived. My mother was almost finished with her plate. After another 15 minutes, I had to flag down a waitress to ask about the sashimi plate. I waited another 15 minutes. My mother had finished eating and wanted me to ask for a box. So, after an hour, the sashimi plate finally arrived. The pieces were really small. Also, we were ready to leave. So I sent the sashimi plate back and refused to pay for it. I usually tip small neighborhood restaurants 25%. This time I tipped only 10%. I don't recommend this restaurant to anyone. They are simply overwhelmed. This restaurant might be okay to visit if: you are alone so no one else but you has to suffer, the weather is bad, you're too lazy to throw a Hungry Man TV dinner in the microwave, you start the meal with TWO bottles of beer to anesthetize you while you deal with the indifferent service, you're so tired you don't care what the food tastes like, and you're trying to save money by not tipping very much. After the meal, walk down the street to a neighborhood bar and slam down three more beers to forget what you just experienced and ate. Two stars for no other reason than because they're a small neighborhood business. Good luck.
author: Steady O.

description:
It's not the best sushi in town, but it's probably the best sushi in town for the prices you'll find here. 

6 piece maki rolls (yellow tail, salmon, tuna) - in the $2.75 - $3 range! The other rolls with more of the fixings are around $5-$9. They also give you complimentary Genmai Cha tea and miso soup (I think edimame too - I can't remember for sure).

I've come twice now, and to give you an example of the bang you get for your buck: trip number 1 - yellowtail maki, sake maki, tuna maki, udon noodle soup, large sake, tempura vegetable appetizer (plus the complimentary tea / miso) - it came to less than $40 total, for the two of us.

The tuna and yellow tail rolls and were delicious, and the salmon roll was good - but I've had better salmon, which is why I can't give 5 stars. It didn't taste fishy, but the texture was kind of tough. And the rolls weren't wrapped very well, but again, for the price, it's really NBD.

The first time we came was at around 4pm on a Sunday (empty), but the second time was on a Friday night at 6:30. That time, we just barely got in before the crowd - I'd recommend coming at a non-peak time if you don't want to wait. Oh, and the atmosphere is cute but not fancy (casual date or meet up with a friend), and the service is good.
author: Jessica C.

description: Horrible! I can't believe others call this Japanese cuisine and loved it! Those people have never had real Japanese cuisine. So over priced for food worse than mall food court food! If I could give it zero stars I would but it's not letting me!
author: christine k.

description: This place is amazing! Low prices and delicious food. I never pass up in sashimi here. It tastes super fresh and it isn't a bad deal. Get it with the combo set and it's totally worth it.
author: Jackie H.

description:
My mom and I love this little sushi spot! Probably because it's only 3 blocks away from us and makes life after taking care of 12 children that much easier!

I don't eat anything raw so I usually get the salmon lover roll (well done) or the udon. My mom gets the sashimi and loves it. Apparently, you can't beat the price! 

You MUST get the chef salad. Their "secret" dressing is to die for and I end up locking the plate! (Classy, I know)

The only problem is the long wait, but obviously for a reason. Although Esther (who swears she isn't the owner...) is amazingly nice, the service is super slow.
author: Anastasia N.

description: My family and I have been coming here for years. The sushi is fresh and they have many excellent specialties. Someone always gets the beef amiyaki, the karaage, and the sashimi. The hostess/waitress, Esther, is friendly and recognizes the regulars. Our favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Nicholas T.

description:
tl;dr ~ NG (no good). It's cheap, and the food you get is cheap. Would not come again.

PROS
- it's cheap.
nigiri are 1.40 ea; sushi and sashimi combos are similarly priced.

- amiyaki is good
fresh, tender, and yummy -- get this if you come here

- cute decor
hey ambiance does sorta matter


CONS
- sushi is godawful
their fish tastes like 1.40 ea
their rice is badly prepared

- poor service
get ready to wait 15m to order
and 20m to pay
author: Ayumi Y.

description:
Wanted sushirito, but settled for this place instead. First time here, not too shabby. After reading the other yelp reviews I expected mediocre service at best and that's exactly what I got. Service needs work, but for the amount of food I ordered, and how small the bill was at the end, I will definitely be back. 

For under ten bucks I got 2 rolls, miso soup, and 8 piece gyoza. Way too much bang for my buck in one sitting. It's cheap, it's good, and it's in my neighborhood. The place is fairly small, so leave your giant amazon friends at home and please try not to bring 8 other people to dinner with you unless you'd like to be sardine packed inside. 

Tasty, cheap dinner? I'm sold.
author: Brenda L.

description: This is by far the best sushi in the outer sunset. It may seem small, but the sushi is delicious and the prices are awesome! The last time I was there, I ordered two spicy tuna rolls, a phili roll, and 3 miso soups to go. It came out to around 15 bucks! The service is fast and the sushi is great every single time. Definitely stop by if your craving sushi in the sunset!
author: Hannah W.

description:
We recently bought a house in the Outer Sunset District and we're glad we found this place.  The food was fresh and delicious.  I agree with everyone here, the Beef Amiyaki melts in your mouth.  The flavor is heavenly and it was cooked perfectly.  We ordered the 49ers roll, Alaskan roll, Sashimi combo, salmon sushi and white tuna sushi; they were all fresh and delightful.  

My ratings are heavily on taste and not so much about service and cleanliness.  If you're into those things, here is my critique about them:

The service was a bit slow because there was only 1 person acting as a host, taking orders, serving and handling the money.  Nevertheless, if you're in good company and not starving, you won't even notice the wait.

The restaurant was intimate and very clean.  Sometimes it would take awhile for the tables to be cleaned because they are understaffed.  

Overall, I rate this restaurant with 5 stars.  The food was great, the price wasn't inflated, the dining room is cozy and the service was welcoming.
author: Dennis D.

description:
Cheap, authentic sushi in the city?  Yes, it does it exist.  

This is a tiny, family-run restaurant.  If you come anytime close to normal dinner time, expect to wait for a table.  Service isn't speedy, but you have to keep in mind that there are only two servers at most.  

On the plus side, they have a pretty extensive menu with specialty rolls, regular sushi, sashimi, bento boxes, gyoza, udon, and some savory meats (beef amiyaki).  The prices are very reasonable--think lunch-like prices for dinner. 

I love love the sauce they put on the spicy tuna rolls--so good.  The sashimi is only okay, but you can't go wrong with most anything else.
author: Lisa N.

description: Love their Beef Amiyaki, very tasty and tender ribeye steak, the Beef Sukiyaki is also good with flavor and thin tender beef, most of the other food are also very good according to my guest and family, it is difficult to find a restaurant with the majority food being good. This is the only restaurant that my entire family will go without argument.
author: Jack W.

description:
Probably one of the better sushi places in SF, nothing pretentious or extravagant with their sushi, but more so authentic and super fresh. Surprisingly delicious for a random place me and the boyfriend decided to try.

Beef Amiyaki- Like most of the other yelpers stated, this is a MUST TRY. Super tender, moist, marinated rib eye serve on a sizzling clay platter. The meat literally melts in your mouth. 

Spicy tuna roll/ dynamite roll- Can't really remember the difference of the taste between the two, but the tuna was super fresh. It was not drenched with siracha or chilli oil, just the perfect hint of spice without overwhelming the tuna.

Tuna Poki- My bf totally loved their tuna poki, but it had a little too much sesame oil on it for me. I was hoping it would be served over a couple pieces of lettuce or something to balance out the sashimi, but it was served as a couple diced pieces of tuna with sesame seeds and green onions.

House salad- Amazing house dressing, there was definitely a strong hint of mustard to it. 

Prices are super reasonable and the waitresses are friendly. The place is small so expect for a wait during lunch and dinner rushes.
author: Ada C.

description:
My parents used to take my sister and I here when we were little kids...the owners later opened up Balboa Teriyaki, which became one of our favorite restaurants until the place got sold...

The prices at this restaurant are seriously straight out of the early 2000s.  The BF and I couldnt believe how cheap everything was!  The beef amiyaki and tamago nigiri have been my favorites since i was a kid, and it still tastes just how i remember it!  i dont know if hte steaks are marinated or what but they're amazing!  The BF got the chirashi and couldn't believe how cheap it was given the portions.

Service here is great too--the servers are very quick on their feet and friendly, too.
author: Jen D.

description: We love coming here with my family. Food is great cheap. Prepare to wait as its a cozy restaurant. Great place to take family and friends.. We have been coming here for years. I love their bento boxes. Service is great, the ladies seem very attentive.
author: Minna M.

description: Pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food, especially the Beef Amiyaki. It was tender, juicy, and flavorful.
