The dinner combo was a really good value - for $12 you get a decent sized salmon teriyaki, and 6 slices of tuna sashimi.  The shrimp tempura appetizer is also a good deal for $5.   Was not so impressed by the Chirashi, however.  The sashimi slices were small, and you only get 4 kinds of fish instead of the usual, wider variety.  I'd stick to the cooked foods, but we'll definitely add this to our usual take out list.
author: Yayu L.

description:
This review for service ~~~Bad service, told us wait is about 10min. Waited like 40min. When our turn came she gave the people behind us our table because they were like more !! Like wtf?

Bad Coustmor service, won't be back again :)
author: Bandar A.

description: Went here with a friend of mine for a Friday Night dinner. Great food and generous portions for the price. We ordered two sushi rolls and combination dinners. We were stuffed. Wait wasn't too long considering that the restaurant is a smaller venue.
author: Nick C.

description: Very good affordable food.  Love the veggie sushi.  I did not enjoy the salmon.  Beef amayaki is very good.  Gyoza are very good.  Wine is $3 a glass!  Very nice folks running the place.  Occasionally we've gotten an off dish, but overall it is a very good value and they are very kind.
author: Genevieve B.

description: I've been coming here some I was a youngin. The sushi is hella fresh-I usually get the maguro. Miso soup is bomb too.
author: Anastasia P.

description: So damn good. And cheap! Wuhh? Yes. Take out is better than waiting 45min for a table tho.
author: Melody V.

description:
I agree with Kiel L... This place is great if you are already in the sunset. The prices for food is lower than many other Japanese restaurants, so if you are looking for the best bang for your buck, you'll want to come here.

Keep in mind that there is normally just one waitress working here so their service is a tad slow. On peak hours, do not come if you are in a rush.

Food is great! No complaints. Good portions, good tasting. They have many dishes on a sizzling skillet (beef, chicken, unagi). They are always amazing. Their Donboris are delicious, Sashimi is good, sushi is affordable, sukiyaki is yummy (always ask for extra noodles bc they give you almost none), and ambiance is quaint. 

Overall, this is my go to Japanese restaurant when I want some good, affordable food  but don't feel like spending $50 like other Japanese places. This is definitely a great staple to have in Sunset. =)
author: Tiffany O.

description:
Well, it's a little (tiny) restaurant run (and I assume owned) by an older Japanese couple. There are potentially 10 tables and they're all crammed into a small space which feels like someone's garage turned restaurant.

Sushi is okay. Mid-lower range sushi but it's cheaper than other places with similar sushi. Sashimi was okay - Not super fresh but not rancid either. Miso soup was better than most other similar Japanese restaurants.

Chicken and Beef teriyaki weren't so great - Wouldn't order those again. Rib-eye was good. I would probably only order the ribeye if returning.
author: Con L.

description: Been going here since I was in my mother's womb... seriously. So after 23 years, I may be a little biased when I say no other Japanese restaurant will ever compare in my book. I'm always caught between recommending it to people and wanting to keep it my little secret so if you're reading this definitely hit this spot up. Beef Amayaki along with a Spider Roll is my go-to every time, but none of the other items on the menu disappoint either.
author: Puka N.

description:
I don't understand all the positive ratings, we had a terrible experience here :( 

The restaurant is closed by our house, another place that's convenient to walk to. We got here at 6:30, had to wait about 30 minutes to be seated. The place is extremely small, and watch the door. It automatically closes so stop trying to close it people. There's a giant sign that tells you that it will close automatically.  

Either way, we were seated, it took another 15 minutes for someone to take our orders. I understand you're busy, but seriously, 15 minutes to take our orders is unacceptable especially if you see us trying to flag you down. Another 20 minutes for our water and miso soup to arrive, and another 15 mins for our salad to arrive, and another 30 minutes for our actual order to arrive. Seriously? No wonder there's a long wait, not only is the restaurant small, it takes forever for everything to come out. They're really understaffed here. This was the longest dinner we ever had, and it wasn't even pleasant. If it wasn't because we had waited for so long, I would have walked out. 

While waiting for our food, we heard an argument between a patron and one of the waitress. Apparently they were already waiting for over an hour and someone else got seated before them. I don't know if that's the norm here, but it did look like the regulars who knew the waitress got seated before others. I can't prove this of course, but the fact that our table was ignored while others were waited hand and foot made it difficult not to feel that way.

Sushi was nothing special. I guess after reading all the positive reviews, we were hoping for really really fresh fish. Not so much. Not to mention, they were flavorless. 

This is not a keeper for us... I rather drive and waste time looking for parking then having to wait here.
author: Angie L.

description: I came bc of the 4 star reviews but it's really not 4 stars.  3 at most! The dragon roll was a 2 star at most.  It was narrow and doesn't look very appetizing.  I order dragon rolls almost every time the restaurant offers it bc I don't eat raw stuff.  The sukiyaki was small and not that great either.  The rice on the nigiri was not good either.  I seriously don't know how they got a 4 star...
author: mayiask k.

description: Very good spot. So glad we found an easy sushi place nearby that doesn't break the bank!
author: Amanda M.

description: Service is quite fast (considering how busy they were - every seat was taken) and the food was very fresh. The sushi rolls were really good - I recommend the Rainbow Roll. I also got the Agedashi Tofu and that was also good. The texture was good and so were the flavors. It was a very plain flavor though, so if you like really bold and strong flavors I don't recommend this dish. The restaurant is super cheap as well! The waitress that served us was very kind and quick. I recommend this place!
author: Fiona M.

description: If you are looking for good Japanese in the Sunset checkout this place. I came here on a late Saturday evening and the wait for 2 was about 30 minutes. Once your inside they have all your typical Japanese stuff. I ordered the dragon roll and the bento box with the salmon. I was really shocked when my salmon came out and it was not dry at all. I've always had dry salmon at Japanese restaurants and this place was the first to breakout from that problem. The roll was alright, not impressive. Would I come back? Sure.
author: Matthew L.

description: Cannot comment on the food because didn't even get to try it. Made reservations last week for the 25th, Friday for 6pm. When our party of 7 arrived, a table was not reserved.  We weren't late as we arrived at 5:50pm. The place is small and the tables were all filled up. We addressed the waitress about our reservations and the other waitress remembered but did not write it down. We had to wait for a table. What is the point of making a reservation? The waitress tried to assure us we would have a table soon but the table that was becoming available could only sit 5 comfortably.  The table adjacent to it was about to become free but they didn't get their bill yet. Just a warning that a reservation may mean nothing and the place is small so expect a wait, if you don't make a reservation. Not sure if I would try to eat here again.
author: N L.

description: I've been going here for over 20 years now and it hasn't changed a bit! I love Sako and Esther, the lead cook and lead waitress. Get the Beef Amiyaki, Chicken wings, Unagi on the skillet, Salmon Teriyaki, Sukiyaki or really anything on the menu. The lines have gotten longer over the years but it hasn't ever discouraged me from waiting. I'm Japanese and can appreciate home grown cooking from grandmas kitchen so this place really hits home for me. If you want authentic comfort foods come here; if you can't deal with  lines and/or parking wars, this probably isn't going to be your place.
author: Brandon I.

description:
Reasonably priced sushi. Definitely our go-to spot ever since we've discovered it, thanks to a friend of ours! Every time we come in, it's with a big group of people though, haha! We take up like half of the restaurant. It's a pretty small place. Yeah service can be a little slow sometimes, but there's only usually one person out front. She's this sweet older lady that remembers us! 

Food!:
Everyone gets a miso soup and tea. Ya gotta request for waters though.
-Beef Amiyaki, so tender and delicious. Comes with a salad and rice. 
-Combo F (I think)! Beef sukiyaki and sashimi combo! The sashimi that they usually give me is Maguro, no complaints. I dig tuna. 
-I also like the House Special bento box. really good price for all the food that you get. :D; it comes with teriyaki (salmon, chicken, or beef), gyoza, sashimi, tempura, and rice and a salad.

As for rolls--they're straightforward and simple. Spicy Scallop Roll, Fujiyama Roll, and Philly Roll are probably our go-tos. :] Sashimi and Nigiri are reasonably priced as well! You get a good amount of fish for the Sashimi combos.
author: Mariel A.

description: This place is great! The food is really good and the price is cheap! Idk why it says 2 dollar signs but I spend about $10-20 depending if I drink or not, SAKE BOMBS! I go for the chicken Katsu about $9, and California rolls, $2-3
author: Rob T.

description: TOTALLY NOT WORTH THAT 4 STARS RATING!!!!!!!! what you pay that's what you get!! they are really cheap but food is not good at all. tuna n other sashimi are not fresh, salmon teriyaki is so fishy (I cannot swallow that kind of bad), tempura shrimp is full of flour and the shrimp is like chopstick thin. but if you only wanna fill you stomach with some cheap Japanese food, go for it.
author: V L.

description:
If you can drive or walk here within 10 minutes (inner+outer sunset), it should be your default sushi restaurant. 

This place wins out because of it's consistency. The food quality, atmosphere and pricing are done well enough that you can come back a couple times a month without feeling guilty. 

For what it's worth, the beef amiyaki smells better than it tastes; I prefer the chirashi dinner combo. So there.
author: Kiel L.

description:
I still frequent this place when I want some Japanese food. The prices have remained low despite a seeming increase in popularity. I haven't recently eaten in (mostly take-out), so I'm not sure about the endless rice, but I hope they keep it up.

With that said, I feel I should admit this just so my reviews remain credible and honest: the tempura has gone down in quality. It's not as airy as it used to be. Instead, it's thickly battered and greasy. My grandmother, unofficial tempura expert, no longer orders the tempura dishes. The sashimi is excellent though and all the other dishes are great, so I still recommend Fujiyama-ya.
author: Kym M.

description:
First time trying sushi EVER. I went here for a friend's birthday and I was pretty happy with my experience!
I tried the Rock & Roll and it was pretty good and cheap. I can't remember the name of it but we all shared a plate of oysters that were delicious and not too spicy!
Also, the saki was pretty good.

Everyone got free tea, free green tea/vanilla ice cream at the end.
And a sample of ginger, edamames, etc.
Would come back again.
author: Analleli G.

description: This is my favorite Sushi place in the city. Wonderful food, great service, and good prices. I LOVE Fujiyama-Ya!!!
author: Steph L.

description: This place is great for so many reasons - friendly and attentive staff, big menu, very affordable prices and tasty food. I got the chicken sukiyaki and my husband got the combo beef sukiyaki with shashimi which we both loved. The sukiyaki was the best I've had so far. The meals also come with tea, a nice sized bowl of miso soup and salad. The oshidashi was also really delicious- they toast the sesame seeds. They also gave us a big tub of rice to split. Will definitely be back.
author: L H.

description:
[M]ona: 4.5 stars
[W]ayne: 4 stars
Average: 4.25 stars

[W] Beware! Bad Classical Music will turn off appetite. If you're facing the kitchen, don't forget to pay attention to the little lady owner because she always seems to be putting on make-up EVERYTIME we go. It's a little distracting but their great food puts my eyes back on track of the good stuff. 

[M] Aside from that, Fujiyama makes really yummy sushi. My BF and I order their Pink Salmon Roll, Alaska Roll, Rainbow Roll, and 49er Roll every time we come!  If you like tons of sauce on your meat, do try their beef teriyaki as well~ :3
author: Mona C.

description:
What hurts the most... is having anticipation for a joint and it letting you down.  Way down.  Down to the ground down.  That's what happened with Fujiyama-Ya and us tonight.  

We'd been hoping to replace an all-time favorite, Ray's Sushi in Hayward but, were sadly disappointed.  Way down.  *sigh*  We walked in with full spirits and loved the cute look of the lil Japanese restaurant.  The wait was a lil long to order but we didn't care too much.  The miso came out... it was above average.  This is where everything started going downhill.

Though the prices were really reasonable, most of the food was a big disappointment.  My gyoza tasted ok but were mushy.  It's like they'd been over boiled/steamed and then lightly seared on the bottom.  Next, the Tuna Lover roll was very salty and had way too much mayo in the crab.  Not a good sign.  When my Dynamite roll came out, it was covered in a gross creamy sauce and the tuna inside was fishy tasting and drenched in a mayo sauce too.  It was mushy.  Gross Gross... I think the 2 of us only ate 3 pieces... which is saying a lot for a couple who rarely wastes food.  The Hamachi Nigiri was stringy and not so good.  The Tekka Don (maguro chirashi) had such a small amount of maguro, I thought they'd made some mistake.  It's taste was ok though.  Also, the udon had nicely chewy noodles but the tempura itself, was SO GREASY that when you pressed a chopstick into it, grease seeped out.  You could taste the oil in the batter.  Gross.

I feel so let down.  I guess that's the danger of hoping for too much.  If you like cheap sushi and Japanese food that is drenched in mayo and grease, this is your joint.  lol.  I know there are people out there who do so I'm trying to be objective. 

Definitely won't see ya there.
author: Susan D.

description: Love this place, the staff is always the same, the food comes out on the slower side but the food is good and the price is cheap. Get the beef amiyaki if you haven't already - tasty, juicy, and tender. I like to order their rolls because they're cheap. 3 orders of the makimono won't break you $15. The customizable entree combos really gives you the opportunity to order exactly what you want. Portions are decent and ever so satisfying.
author: Ryan L.

description: loved going to this place before, but recent experience was that the quality of food has gone down.  The gyoza was not cooked thoroughly and tastes like from frozen, sashimi pieces have gone to very small pieces, the taste overall got more bland.
author: F K.

description:
I love the service and the food here. I always get the bento box or the beef amiyaki, if they havent sold out of it. Im sure theres a ton of reviews on the beef amiyaki so I wont even talk about that. The bento box is a great deal if youre really hungry. It'll fill you up and includes a ton of stuff like a salad, soup, entree, gyoza, sashimi, etc. Their sushi isnt bad either; I prefer the spicy tuna.

They have Japanese beer and a nice Japanese decor. Located in a non-competitive spot on Noriega, this place is better than Noriega Teriyaki (if youre deciding on Japanese food in the area) so try this place first.
author: Tim M.

description:
My roommate came back with the poke sushi roll with seaweed for dinner one day and ever since then I wanted to check this place out.  

The reviews are true.  The beef amiyaki is a very tasty dish, but otherwise I thought everything else was pretty standard when it came to Japanese food.  The sushi rolls and sashimi are good bargains for the price, but are nothing out of the ordinary.  This is a restaurant I can see myself coming to get dinner to go or get myself a fix of Japanese food, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come by.  Also, the wait for the food was a bit long - but we were there on a weekend night during dinner hours so I'll give them a little more leeway on that front.
author: Michele P.

description: NOT GOOD! Horrible Japanese food. The ratings are pure lies! Not sure how this place got 4 stars. The Beef Amiyaki was dry and just drenched in a salty sauce. There was no beef flavor. You could probably get something similar at Yoshinoya. Hands down, the worst sushi place i've been to in SF. Sashimi was not fresh, and I got sick from eating the sashimi here. Curled up in the fetal position sick, not your run of the mill indigestion. If you are still going to eat here after reading this review, make sure whatever you order is cooked. DO NOT eat the raw stuff, unless being curled up in the fetal position writhing in pain and camping out on your toilet is your idea of a good time.
author: Ernest N.

description:
My favorite dish is their beef sukiyaki.  You can find beef sukiyaki on many Japanese restaurant menus; however, Fujiyama-Ya's can't be beat.  Comes in a typical cast iron kettle with plenty of tender sliced beef in a great broth.  If you like beef sukiyaki, try it here.  You can order it as part of a combination dinner or order it separately.

Highly recommended, especially on a cold foggy San Francisco night.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I really hate to give the rating I did, especially since the staff here is nice.  The one thing that drove me to do that is that spicy yellowtail roll I ordered, it was much bonier than I felt it should be.  I don't believe I experienced something like that before.  Three of the six pieces I had to pull out a fish bone while chewing, and for one particular piece it was pretty sizable.

Otherwise, if not for that, I would have said the sashimi was overall fine given the menu prices I wasn't expecting much.  I would have been impressed that they gave pretty sizable pieces for my chirashi combo, although the salmon's freshness level seemed less tha ideal. Still, I may have forgiven that if it wasn't for the excessive fish bones in the yellowtail roll.
author: H K.

description: Went here with a couple friends the other night, the place was really well priced, it's not the best sushi I've had but pretty good spot within walking distance.  It seems like a little cute family owned place we went here because there were many people and the place across the street was completely empty which is never a good sign.  Will most likely come back again when I want a good deal on sushi.
author: Nirea S.

description:
I really did want to like this place. After reading all the positive reviews on this place, I was pretty optimistic. Apparently Fujiyama-Ya prides itself on 2 things: quality of food and affordability. Unfortunately it only delivered on the latter. 

I've tried Fujiyama-Ya a couple times, giving them a couple times to get it right with the raw fish. The first time I came, I ordered the tonkatsu donburi with a side of hamachi sashimi. The tonkatsu was cut up into ridiculously tiny bits so you really didn't get much meat. And I feel like chopping the meat so small was really done to conceal the fact that it probably a lesser cut of pork. But I could be wrong. The hamachi was really fishy tasting and was kind of hacked up. The second time I came I ordered the sashimi dinner. Again, everything tasted really fishy. They give you a good amount of fish, but my tuna was mushy, salmon was tough and chewy, and the hamachi just plain tasted bad. Also, the cut job on the fish was horrendous. I made the mistake of posting a picture of my meal on instagram (who knows why I did it...the plate did not even look pretty...) and one of my friends asked me if I'd cut the fish myself. 

To top it off, the service I received both times was not very good. There are a good amount of waitresses (3-4) and each time I've come they haven't been very busy. Which would usually mean that service would be great. But it wasn't. Food came out very slowly and the waitresses were very slow to take our order and deliver our check. On my first visit, one of the waitresses got my friend's order wrong. 

So yes, this place is cheap. But I would rather pay a little more and get better service and better food. It is a sad sad day when I admit that I would rather go to Kiki's on 9th Avenue. But I would.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
I love this place! Its kind of a hole in the wall.  

Anyway, this place is delicious!  I've always gotten teriyaki or katsu, but I decided to try the beef amiyaki this time and it was freaking delicious!  My stomach is getting more hungry as I am thinking about this.  Yummmm.

It can be noisy when people are drinking sake bombs, but other than that the environment is okay.

There is a weird picture on the wall where it looks like a japanese guy is peeing.  Ha.
author: Tina L.

description: The food is absolutely PHENOMENAL. Wonderful staff of workers that welcome you with open arms. The beef amiyaki is to DIE for. Ester is the best waitress I've ever encountered. I would recommend this place in a heartbeat. I will be taking my family and future kids here for as long as they remain open!
author: Rob S.

description:
Came here with a friend for dinner last night. This place is quite small and has around ten tables. I wouldn't recommend coming here if you have a large party, it would be great for groups of four. We got here at around 6:30PM and was able to be seated in about 10 minutes. They serve complimentary miso soup so that was much appreciated on a cold night.

I initially wanted to try their beef amiykai since it's seems to be the highlight of the majority of the reviews on here, but unfortunately I still haven't digested my lunch so I just ended up ordering maki rolls.

My mind is blanking right now so I can't remember the names. One came with salmon and avocado and the other unagi and avocado with 6 rolls per order. Both are pretty standard as with any sushi restaurant. I was happy to bite into salmon that was fresh, chewy, and soft. Many places tend to use cheap salmon that leave streaks of salmon between your teeth (ew). The unagi had subtle, yet tasty flavor. I enjoyed popping the bite-sized pieces in my mouth as my friend and I caught up. 

In addition, I ordered shiro maguro nigiri. The odd (but good) thing about this place is that they sell it by the piece, rather than two pieces. It was nice and soft but lacked flavor. I saved this for last so I was a little dissapointed. 

My friend ordered chicken karaage that came with rice. They don't fry it as long as other places so it ended not being crunchy enough, but the chicken still had good flavor.

Maybe our orders were kind of boring but everything came out as decent. Not a bad place but not a "must-try".
author: Mei H.

description:
FAVORITE JAPANESE RESTUARANT IN SUNSET HANDS DOWN!

I'm a lover for bento boxes because it offers you a wide range of everything. BUT THE HOUSE SPECIAL BENTO BOX HERE IS AHMAZING! It comes with your choice of beef/chicken/salmon teriyaki with shrimp/veggie tempura, sasimi, gyozas, rice, miso soup, salad, and rice for only $14.95 WHAAAT A DEALLLL! I based this on every other bento boxes I've had at other places but they do not come in this package.

Anyways besides their amazing bento boxes, they do offer a wide range of japanese food such as the BEEF AMIYAKI (drools all the time), sushi rolls, other bento boxes, noodle bowls, ETC

This place is small and it can get busy so I would suggest to make reservations if you have large parties attending or on busy weekends.
author: Virginia L.

description:
Better than 'Wasabi' across the street.  But...there's always a but isn't there?  So, been here a couple of times and forgot why I hadn't been in a while.  I was reminded tonight!  Small crapped space?  Nope, not the reason.  No place to stand while waiting for a table?  Ummm, no.  Take a damn long time to give you your food?  Uh-un.  Not that either.  Was it because they only give you cheap ass tuna as the sashimi side dish with combos and bento?  Bingo!  Yeah, that's it.

After I ordered my dish, I heard other customers requesting all salmon for their sashimi.  I thought that odd and found out why when all our dishes arrived - all 3 of them tuna, tuna and tuna sashimi.  Dang Fujiyama-Ya, that's a little bit, I don't know?  What's the motivation behind that anyway?

If you do go here, just remember to ask for something other than tuna if you order a combo or bento with sashimi, like salmon maybe and another type of fish.
author: barry a.

description: Beef ameyaki (grilled, marinated rib eye) is my favorite - tender and flavorful.  We also ordered a tempura appetizer, which was nice and crispy, and a combo chirashi bowl, which had four different kinds of fish (16 pcs total).  Overall, definitely a great meal and would go again just for the beef ameyaki.
author: Erick L.

description: I came here on a Friday night at 7:30. There was already a line, but tables were turning over quickly as the first dinner rush left. After waiting for about 10-15 min, my party of 3 was seated in a booth. We ordered a sashimi combo, the beef amiyaki, one sushi roll, and shrimp tempura. Dinner entrees come with miso soup, house salad, and rice. The sashimi was fresh (unlike some other reviews and the salmon was especially marbled), the beef amiyaki was tender and sizzling on the hot plate, and service was prompt and friendly. I'll be back.
author: Jojo H.

description:
My family has been going here for over a decade, so I am a little biased. But that tenure speaks to how consistently delicious they are! Esther, the main server, who has been running this place for forever, is so sweet and has always treated us with excellent service. I do hope they can get more consistent help for her as it can get kinda slow when it gets busy. 

The restaurant is small with only ten or so tables, so it fills up quickly. There are individual tables that can be pushed together for large groups, and there are booths as well. The decor is just like a traditional Japanese restaurant but is very casual and homey at the same time.

We've probably tried everything on the menu, but all of your traditional Japanese dishes are good and reasonably priced.. We always get the beef amiyaki and the seafood nabiyaki. Their agadashi tofu is also one of the best I've had. The raw fish is always fresh as well. 

I hope they never go out of business - a true local gem!
author: Jen L.

description:
cozy little restaurant.  only one waiter, so service is pretty slow.
had the combo with salmon teriyaki and unagi teryaki.  nothing special, both is just doused with teriyaki sauce.  gyoza and agedashi tofu is disappointing.
author: Karen L.

description: Better than average place. Somewhat small so wait time can be long.  They also need to change the sign in placard,  its a whiteboard, some one who came like 1/2 hr after us put his name above ours and his sign in time is earlier than me.  What a rude sob.
author: Erik Y.

description:
dirt cheap. fish is fresh enough, but sushi is put together poorly. hard to pick up with chopsticks because it falls apart quickly. you better shovel it into your mouth quickly!
beef amiyaki is good, comes out sizzling on a black platter and has a sweetness to it.
author: Susy C.

description: 30 years we've been coming. Love Esther, she's like an Aunt to us. Best Japanese food in the city. Best gyoza. Love it. Please tip well - they work hard and deserve it!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Fujiyama-Ya definitely earns its 4-star rating. The food is slightly cheaper than nearby Japanese restaurants, the service is excellent, and the food is delicious!

My only complaint was the wait for a Saturday night. I called in a reservation four hours in advance and when we got there sharp, restaurant was full waiting on patrons. One table took FOREVER to finish after they paid their bill.  I almost felt bad for the table of 8, they waited twice the time we did. It was a cold night and I was hungry.

I. The food
The rolls were very good, and the plentiful for what was ordered. I spent only 16 dollars got 1 Maki Roll Plus the Deluxe sushi plate. I like California rolls like the next guy, but the other rolls on the deluxe plate were quite good.

My friend ordered their version of chirashi, and it was a huge box of fish and rice. It was plentiful, it was good.

While we did not get it, the sizzling plates can be heard and smelled. It sounded and smelled very good. Perhaps I will get these next time. 

II. The price
We had a table of 4 and we all ordered at least two things per person, and the bill ended up being $64 or so. I found it reasonable for a Japanese restaurant where I ordered I bunch of rolls of good quality.

III. Service
Aside from my original complaint in the first place. The service was top notch. They were extremely attentive when seated and very nice about assuring us that a table was ready, and asking whether we were full instead of rushing us out even though there were people outside still waiting.

IV. Decor
I know a lot of folks find that these places are hokey in their attempt to copy Edo-style restaurants, but I always love it when restaurants try to give you good decor with your dining experience. I certainly enjoyed it even though the tables were a bit sticky. The art work was definitely a talking point during the meal.
author: Michael C.

description: This place has great Japanese food for awesome prices. The owners are very attentive and generous despite busy crowds. They once brought me some miso soup accidentally after I mentioned that I am a vegetarian. Without a second thought, some gratis veggie gyoza appeared on our table! I thought it was a very sweet touch. Love this local spot... highly recommend the agedashi tofu!
author: Jasmine M.

description: Holy crap, can you say bang for your buck? You get free miso soup, and even when you order several plates of sushi, your meal always comes out cheaper than expected. The sashimi is very fresh and tasty (especially the yellowtail!), and the tempura roll is nice and crunchy. As to be expected, the budget prices attract a crowd, so keep in mind you might have to wait for a table. (I got lucky and was seated right away, but noticed a line building up as I was eating.) Fujiyama-Ya has been my best SF sushi experience yet -- I definitely plan on becoming a regular!
author: Tiffany W.

description: The chirashi bowl is the best here for the price. You can pick two types of sashimi with the chirashi combo. This place gets super crowded Friday evenings around 7 pm and service can get slow at that time. Arrive early!
author: Stella T.

description:
A little neighborhood spot that always 'takes care.'
Like one of those friends you know you can always count on....
I just don't know how to place it better than that.
Gochisoosamadeshita!
author: Barry A.

description:
I am guessing that Esther that everyone is talking about is the lady who works here everyday! She is amazing! 

Food is great too. Tried their teriyaki, donburi, rolls, and sukiyaki. I think this place is more about comfort food... feels like eating at home. Everything is reasonably priced and tasty enough. They also serve sake, wine and beer. Decor is simple and nice. This is the kind of place where you'll come when you are hungry, want Japanese food, and don't know where to go. It won't disappoint, but won't fly you to the moon either. 

Easy parking, and dessert house (Golden Island) is just around the corner!
author: Marlis T.

description: We went on a Thursday evening around 6:30 & the place was pretty full. We had to wait maybe 5-10 min for a table. Pretty small place. My son said he imagines that this restaurant is what a restaurant in Japan is actually like. We had 3 different sushi rolls, 2 reg @$3.95 ea & 1 special @$7.95...all yummy! Hubby ordered special combo, son 2item combo, & I ordered beef amiyaki dinner. All very good! We were all happy w/our choices. All in all, the bill came out to $75 tax & tip included. One note, my son's combo was the amiyaki & tempura & I ordered only the amiyaki. Our beef portions were almost identical. So if you want to try something else w/the beef, don't worry that the beef portion will be too small. It might've been a dollar more for the combo plate. Yes, we would go back!
author: susan w.

description:
Love the location (so close to home!) especially when I am in the mood for Japanese.

I never ate in the restaurant yet but take out was quick and easy.

Take out dinner:
1. Rainbow roll -- Made fresh and the roll was pretty big. 
2. Chirashi bowl -- My all time favorite Chirashi bowl has to be from Yum Yum fish but Fujiyama's was pretty good too. The tuna, salmon and hibachi was cut fresh and i love the little bits of tamago in my rice.

Overall, I was pretty satisfied with my dinner and the total bill.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Sushi is nice. Not many Japanese restaurant allows you to order the sushi piece-by-piece, but you can do it and that's great if you wanna try more varieties. 

A hot sake is good.
It's a small but cozy, not my favourite, but it's OK.  I expect the lighting to be dimmer and feels even more cozy!
The Beef amiyaki is a perfect combination with hot sake.  Price is reasonable, but not that cheap.

Parking is easy to find, so that's a plus.


I had a food allergy from the fried shrimp head.  Not sure why but I can't believe the last time I had food allergy.  I take off 1 star because of this. But it could be just me.


And that waitress is very really sweet and cute (too bad, forgot to ask her name)
author: Sam X.

description:
I hate being the odd one out here but my experience was so crappy here. Yelp, you have disappointed me. : ( I don't know if its because we came here on a Friday night around 8. It was sort of busy but its a small restaurant and they had 3 waitresses. The service was mediocre but maybe leaning towards the crappier side. Two of the older lady waitresses were pretty nice but the other younger one with glasses was pretty rude. We asked her like 4 times for our water and our diet pepsi. 

We ordered the vegetable donburi, special bento box, spicy tuna roll, and chicken teriyaki and salmon teryiyaki entree. They all came with soup and salad. The waitresses served us one salad short and didn't give the third one til we were almost done with our food. We also had to ask for tea which usually comes in the beginning of the meal along with the water and drinks.

My cousin like the vegetable donburi but I don't think it looked or tasted that great. The special bento box was just meh. The tuna sashimi tasted so fishy and disgusting that I had to spit it out. It wasn't even fresh. The gyoza was ok along with the tempura. Tasted like any other kind that I've had. The only upside was the beef teriyaki. It tasted really tender and flavorful. I think that was the only appetizing part of the bento.

The spicy tuna roll was poorly made and the consistency was like real tuna. It was really weird. It didn't taste bad, just never tasted spicy tuna like that before. The chicken teriyaki and salmon were alright. The salmon actually served was a big piece and was pretty tender which is good.

In conclusion, the service was not that good along with the food. Maybe if I come here on a slow night than maybe the food would be better with the service. One upside though is that their rolls are pretty cheap. Other than that, I will be going to other places in the sunset/richmond district.
author: Fran N.

description: This place seriously has the best nigiri I've ever eaten (my previous favorites were Kiji and Sanraku, both very solid). We ordered the shake (salmon), hamachi (yellowtail), maguro (tuna), and uni (sea urchin). Everything was super fresh. The uni was rich and buttery. The shake, hamachi, and maguro all were mild yet flavorful, with the pieces almost melting in my mouth. In addition to the sushi being superior to what I've experienced before, the prices were very reasonable. Only $1.40 per piece. I will definitely be going back regularly!
author: Deidre E.

description:
My family and friends have been going to this restaurant for more years than we can remember.... 25+?

This is a neighborhood place where you go for a consistent favorite and flavor like going to a second home when you don't want to cook. It's frequented by locals & long-time return customers. Don't expect anything fancy or flashy here. It's good affordable Japanese comfort food!

They have a fairly diverse menu. The sashimi & nigiri sushi & rolls may not be as fancy as other higher end Sushi restaurants, but it's fresh and most affordable. The Beef Amiyaki rib eye steak is a winner, as is their Spider, Spicy Tuna and Dynamite Rolls!  And their Uni... very fresh! They have a good Lemon Chicken for those not into Japanese flavor. They also have beer, Sake and Plum wine for those wanting something stronger than Green Tea or soda. 

Did I mention Esther, the waitress? She's usually the person who greets  you when you arrive. Esther is friendly and the public face of Fujiyama-ya since she literally works each table. So be patience when the place is full. She's friendly and tries to please, but sometimes it gets stressful when everyone suddenly shows up and she's short-handed at Fujiyama-Ya. 

If you enjoyed the food, please take the time to thank the cooks in the kitchen and express your appreciation for their cooking and hard work.
author: Edward H.

description: I came here after I saw Yelp reviews.Cute, small restaurant. And the food is pretty good. I ordered a Chicken Teriyaki and Sashimi combo for $12. Keep in mind,every entree comes with miso soup, salad, rice, and green tea... So I thought the pricing was pretty decent. Overall, I would recommend!!
author: Jennifer H.

description: We've been coming here for 28 years!!!, Esther the waitress is a gem, though at times being the only waitress server, so service can be utterly frustrating at times.  The kitchen expedites the food not by tables but by food items, so  that could be the reason.  The tempura is the best, crisp, not greasy and is able to maintain its crispiness on your plate throughout your meal.  Their salmon teriyaki is cooked to perfection. A steal at $10.95 dinner.  Non of the fish ever smells like fish which is a testament to the freshness of their ingredients.  Their Amayaki rib eye steak is one of my favorites along with their sushi and sashimi dishes and combos.  Their prices are so reasonable.  It is worth the wait. and if you can't,  order to go over the phone.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
A small mom and pop shop lives on in the Sunset!

After a delayed wait due to a mix up in our reservation, our party of ten finally took over.  And I do mean took over.  I've only been here once or twice, but my siblings have recently become weekly patrons as a result of some very personal service to a 5 year old.

For a Sunday night, it was very busy...as in people waiting outside busy. So I was very sorry for everyone else because they had to wait a long time for their food and for any service.  Yes, there was only the one waitress the night we were there and she was running up and down like no tomorrow.  

We ordered a lot of sushi and a couple of entrees.  Since I never had their rolls before, I was pleasantly surprised.  They also sell their nigiri by the piece, but it's not too expensive.

* Uni "sea urchin" ($1.80/pp)

* Amaebi "sweet raw prawn" ($2.40/pp), including the fried shrimp head

*  Spider Roll "soft shell crab" ($5.95/8 pieces) - It was okay, not my favorite.

* Dynamite Roll "tuna, hamachi, avocado with spicy sauce" ($5.95/8 pieces) - I like how they do their spicy sauce, and the avocado with it is nice.  

* Spicy Tuna Roll ($2.95/6 pieces) - I'm digging this...less than three bucks for a 6 piece spicy tuna roll?  I'm definitely coming back for this!

* 49ers Roll "scallop, tobiko inside and tuna, salmon on top" ($8.95/8 pieces) - The tobiko was on the outside instead of inside, which was fine.  And I like the spicy sauce they use here and it tastes good with the scallop.

My nephew loves this place - they give him broccoli tempura because he only likes broccoli.  (Yeah, a five year old that just loves broccoli!)  He also loves it because they remember that he doesn't like green onions in his miso soup.  And they also make him a special ikura maki roll, which is pretty darn good and I wish it was on the menu.  (They forgot his salad this time though.)

With only one sushi order mix up, the rest of the food came out fine.  Sure, we had to wave her down for more tea, water, sushi plates, etc.  But sometimes you don't mind a little wait in mom and pop shops.  The overall product is worth the wait.  But I did feel sorry for all the other patrons who waited a long time to get their order in and for their food to come out.  Sorry!

I love spicy rolls - spicy tuna rolls, spicy hamachi rolls, spicy scallop rolls. But I hate that sriracha stuff in my spicy sauce.  And I like it creamy, especially when it's made with Japanese mayo.  And this place does it the way I like.  That makes me happy.

When you want a simple Japanese dinner, Fujiyama-Ya fits the bill.
author: Teri C.

description:
i cant believe i've never been here! i feel like there aren't too many sushi places in the outer sunset, i'm so glad i stumbled upon this place. bf and i came on a monday night and the place was packed. service was a little slow, yes, but its a tiny place, i can't imagine how small the kitchen is. 

four rolls, a giant chicken katsu bento box, miso soup, and green tea was only $32. and it was all delicious. will DEFINITELY be back! :)
author: Liz M.

description:
03.04.14 w one other

Always a great experience when we make our way here 

Good food and friendly service for this neighborhood spot. 

Usually I go for the bento box here 
So the review is not for the sushi
author: Jay R.

description:
Cheap prices and help my sushi cravings without a big dent in my wallet like some other places that I love. 

Tomago nigiri was just sweet enough and I love that it's only $1. Normally I wouldn't get it cause it's usually like $2 a piece! hahaha not I get 2 for the price of 1 at other places. 

Crunchy roll was delicious. I would definitely recommend getting the rolls because the raw fish nigiri was as fresh as other places. But can't really complain for the price of it. If you're not a big raw fish fan, this place is definitely more worth it than other japanese places around town. 

The tempura's portion was huge! Definitely will fill you up.
author: Christina N.

description:
So one of my favorite foods is sushi, and this is not a place I want to go again...

There was a short wait (10 mins) for the restaurant on a Wednesday night, so we figured it would be alright.

We were seated after the lady took almost 10 minutes to clear off the table. We ordered a dragon roll, chirashi bowl, spider roll and philidelphia roll for 3 people.

Dragon Roll: The unagi was very bland and the tempura had no shrimp in it, it was just batter! 

Spider Roll: It was weird because the (s) size was $3.95 but the large size was $6.95 for only 2 more pieces? So we stuck with the small and I'm glad we did. That thing had no flavor whatsoever.

Phillidelphia roll: The cream cheese overpowered the sushi

Chirashi bowl: you would think this would come before all the cooked rolls but this came almost 15 minutes after we FINISHED the other rolls. Firstly, the sashimi in it was the most basic you could put in there (hamachi, maguro, sake, and one more i forget...) on top of vinegar rice and yet it took them more than 40 minutes. Secondly, the quality is lackluster. I'm not the pickiest person when it comes to sashimi/sushi but man was it atrocious.

Lastly, the service was super slow. there were two ladies serving the 10 or 12 tables, yet it took them forever for a refill of tea, clean the table, and bring us food. We walked our bill up to them so that they could give it back to us faster.

They even accidentally gave us two dragon rolls and charged us for one but even I am not cheap enough to eat that free but lackluster food.
author: Wilson T.

description:
Food was decent, but the service was lackluster.  They never asked us if we wanted anything to drink, and we had to ask them why one of our entrees was taking so long to come out.  Additionally, they did not bring us dessert (which should have came with what we ordered).  

Don't think I am going back any time soon.
author: Jeff H.

description: Very, very bland food. Sub-par sashimi and terrible service. This is probably the worst sushi place I've been to in sf as far as bland/low-quality Japanese food. The rolls had way too much rice too. Even Sushi Zen which I don't particularly care for is wayyyy better. Just a few blocks down on taraval.  Definitely don't understand why this place was packed!!  I usually spend about $30 per person at a sushi restaurant because we collectively eat so much. My bf and I only ran a $28 tab because everything sucked and we went and ate elsewhere afterward.
author: Amber R.

description: We were craving sushi while visiting San Francisco on our honeymoon. We didn't want to go far, and this place was in walking distance. We went in, were seated, ordered, and received our food all within a few minutes. Great food and super fast service! The sushi was delicious!
author: Ruthie R.

description:
Small mom & pop shop.
Friendly service.
Good Prices

Good Food
-Rolls are fresh and pretty cheap compared to other japanese restaurants
-Tempura is a popular dish people get. 

Don't come here and expect to get in and get out. It is a small place and there is only a handful of people working. A nice place to go out for dinner though.
author: Erica L.

description: The food is not good quality. We ordered the teriyaki beef; the meat was so thin and the texture was so strange, I wondered if it was really beef.  The raw tuna looked dry and not fresh, I didn't want to eat it.  It's the type of place you hope you don't get sick after eating the food.  Sorry for the bad review, but the people were nice.
author: E F.

description: Nothing really stood out to me about this place when I could probably go down within a 10 block radius and find better sushi. Maybe it was just our group but when we came here the raw stuff in our sushi was extra chewy and the rice was dry and Chrispy like it was really old rice that they left in the fridge and brought out to use. I was really disappointed. My friends thought it was okay. We all agree we've had better. They did give us complementary miso soup tho.
author: Sophie C.

description: Great food, service and prices.  Esther is da bomb.
author: Dkac C.

description:
Just went here for dinner tonight and it was lame. Place is tiny. Parking tough.

Service was excellent. Waitress sat us immediately and brought out our free miso soup and tea. Both were hot and delicious!

But as for the main course, it was not satisfying to my eyes nor mouth D:

We ordered the basics:
1) california roll: it was just a stick of imitation crab with avocado... they didn't even chop up the crab and add mayo. And I can understand if that's how they always serve it there, but in the picture, it's done chopped up with mayo! Why does it look completely different served??

2) spicy tuna: didn't taste really good and the filing was an orangish color instead of red the way a spicy tuna should be...

3) sunset roll: salmon and avocado on the inside, topped with tuna and hamachi. There was way more tuna than hamachi and the fish was alright but not super fresh. I then investigated the freshness of the salmon so I removed the salmon from the rice and it was cut in a fashion where it looked like she tore a piece from the filet. It looked like it was chewed already or something... horrible presentation!!!

one star for the service
one star for the prices  (total was about 20 bucks)
author: Linda N.

description: This is very small sushi place. I order dragon roll n spicy scallop...the dragon roll is not crunchy at all, the ell tasted weird like its not fresh and still had a lot bone left. Spicy scallop is OK but not that fresh, the beef amiyaki smelt burnt and the potion is.kinda small. The agedashi s vey cheap, they gave me 6 pieces but the sauce is plain. The gyoza is very good though. The lady who served me is slow n neglected,  she put my food in someones table. N it took me 3 times to ask for a ck. So if u wanna eat sushi for cheap then I.recommend this place but to me its not that good for a 4 star restaurant
author: Lily H.

description:
I went here with my cousins, on our usual fatty outings.

I got the veggie tempura donburi, which i enjoyed.

However, the service was crapppyyyyyyy. The older woman working was nicer, but the younger woman was a complete idiot. Seriously, we had to ask her 3 times to bring us tea and water, then she forgot the water, then she forgot my cousins diet coke. She seemed to be in a huff the whole time too.
author: Alison A.

description:
I've eaten there twice, both for dinner, and I really like the place. I've ordered the california roll, rainbow roll, chicken and steak amiyaki, and the sashimi combo. The california roll was better than standard. The second time I got the rainbow roll the fish didn't look too fresh so I was disappointed, but the chicken and steak amiyaki was always made perfect with the right flavor and tenderness; even my 90 year old grandma had no problem eating it with the few teeth she had left! The sashimi combo was very fresh and didn't have the stringy stuff you find with below average sashimi. 

Each time I've eaten there I got miso soup, a salad which has this wonderfully sweet, but not too sweet dressing, and tea. I believe the soup and salad is only given depending on what you ordered... 

Overall the price is very affordable, but major cons are the parking and wait time. At night, parking is hard and at times vicious - you know how hungry people can get in the sunset :P The wait is the worst. I came by 6:20 pm on a friday night and had to wait ~50 minutes to get a table for 2 - people take their time there to eat. They have lovely chefs and waitresses but they're busy and the food is also brought out slowly so there's more waiting you have to do. (I, however, don't really mind it hence the 4/5 stars since I do know this is a family-owned business.) I would highly recommend you make reservations if you know in advance you're going to eat there. Unfortunately this is also a very small restaurant so tables fit a max of 4 people comfortably. 

Happy eatings!
author: Kristine C.

description:
This place has been here for years? What?

I guess I must get my inability to explore restaurants other than the regular ones from my parents because this place is actually pretty good! I frequent Eagles Drift In (I like empty dive bars) but have never thought to stop in to eat here. 

What brought me out of my bubble was a school friend who picked some sushi up from here. Putting that first piece in my mouth, I didn't expect much... but boy was I wrong. After coming out of my sushi bliss, I exclaimed, "where the hell did you get this?!"

I had a chance to finally go in about a week or two ago and walked in a little late (near closing time). They still sat us down and we didn't feel rushed at all. I looked at the menu and saw the CHEAP prices for the sushi and nigiri. I usually order simple rolls (negihama, philadelphia, etc) because I really enjoy the basic flavors. These rolls were only $4-5 each (cheap, as compared to the usual $6 elsewhere). The specialty rolls were also cheap.

I also ordered two pieces of saba nigiri - yuck. The mackerel was dry and skimpy, definitely not getting this again. 

At the suggestion of Yelp, I also ordered the amiyaki. It was delicious - but it definitely had garlic in it (which I am allergic to and had to pay the price for later) but it's almost worth it to eat it again even though my body doesn't like it.

All in all, not the best place for sushi but with the great prices and quality given, i'll be coming back again.
author: Christina B.

description:
Was looking for late night Japanese dinner nearby & was not familiar with the area...checked mobile Yelp on my phone and chose Fujiyama-Ya based on the total average Yelp rating. I agree with the Yelpers, this is a great find: good value & reasonably priced for authentic washoku. Homestyle, like okaasan used to make. :-) And they are open for dinner 7 days a week. :-)

The highlight of our meal was the Tiger Roll, made of softshell crab & avocado, topped with eel and tobiko. We also enjoyed the agedashi tofu.

I had the Chirashi Combo, which was 4 varieties of sashimi on top of sushi rice with nori & tamago. My only disappointment was that I was expecting more of a variety of toppings (e.g. a piece of ebi, some ikura, ika, etc.etc.) since the Chirashi Combo is slightly more expensive than standard chirashi...not sure how the two types of Chirashi are different. (Perhaps this was more expensive b/c it included 20 pieces of nice sashimi.)

My friends enjoyed their Chicken Katsu meal. We were all very full afterwards.

The edamame was too salty for our taste (I am sodium sensitive), so next time I will request if they can avoid putting salt on. Low sodium shoyu is available on request.

Looking forward to coming back soon and trying the other menu items. :-)
author: N. F.

description:
Nothing puts a smile on my face quicker than a visit to Fujiyama-Ya's. I've been coming here for almost 20 years, and it never disappoints. 

Service: Everybody Loves Ester! 

Sushi: First of all, Fujiyama-Ya is NOT known for its sushi. However its pretty descent, and you cant beat the price. California roll, Spicy Tuna roll, and Tempura Maki all between $3 to $4. I always ask them to deep fry my Spicy Tuna roll and Tempura maki in tempura batter. SO GOOD! 

Food: Food is flavorful and delicious. I usually order the make your own combo option. I have tried most of the items on their menu, but I do have my favorites. 

  Green Salad: 5/5 (All about that Honey Mustard Dressing)
    
  Sukiyaki: 5/5 (Broth = great flavor, beef = nice and tender)

  Chicken Karage: 5/5 (Thats some Good Fricken Chicken)

   Beef Amiyaki: 5/5 (Fujiyama's signature dish) 
 
   Rice: Unlimited refills =D 

Their food speaks for itself. Fujiyama-Ya is a perfect example of how Hole-In-The-Walls have the Best Food. Its definitely worth a try.
author: Spencer W.

description: Love Fujiyama-Ya! As others have said, their beef amiyaki is delicious and somebody at the table always gets it, if not several of us!  My son always asks for a separate plate so he can put his beef on it as soon as it arrives at the table; that keeps the beef from overcooking on the hot plate on which it arrives.  It's great that they allow you to make your own combo and include beef amiyaki as one of the items.  The portions are huge and the prices are reasonable. The venue is small, so there's usually a line; also, it gets a bit crowded at the table, epecially with all the food on it!
author: Annie W.

description:
Probably one the cheapest places in the city where you can eat Japanese food at! Granted, it's not the best, but compared to other places, it's decent.

Miso soup seems a bit watered down. The salad dressing on the salad is pretty good though. Beef amiyaki here is definitely really tasty. Not overcooked and very flavorful. I've tried the chicken teriyaki here before too and it's tasty, not burnt and not too much teriyaki sauce drenched over either. The tempura... the day that I got it wasn't that good though. Not sure if that's how it always is, or just an off day... but the batter wasn't really tasty and was kind of soggy. I like my tempura nice and crispy! Rolls here are pretty cheap too. Got the rock and roll, which was decent. Most favorite roll was the 49ers roll, wish they put more salmon on top but regardless, it was very flavorful. Dynamite roll tasted like an ordinary dynamite roll to me, didn't care too much for the sauce on top. My least favorite was the dragon roll which is usually my most favorite roll at other places. However, at Fujiyama, the dragon roll here is sweet... which really threw me off.

Overall, the food here is pretty good and really cheap. Service... as others said... is a little bit off. Waits can be a while since it's a small place. Food can take forever to come. All your food for the table doesn't come together either since our table slowly got their food... which is weird cause everyone tells you to eat before your food gets cold, but if you eat without everyone else... seems kind of wrong... but at the same time my food is getting cold! So, they should work on a way to get the food out to the entire table instead of literally 1 person at a time at different tables.
author: Johnson S.

description:
A couple things that I like about this place. Reasonable Japanese food, decent food and comfortable place to dine in. And judging from the recent reviews, it's very much like a family-friendly restaurant. 

I got myself the Chicken Kaarage entree and it is an interesting way of making it. Chicken Kaarage that I usually have are pieces of chicken deep-fried to a crispy nugget. The way Fujiyama does it was almost like having a light batter that resembles beer-battered fish. The portion size is pretty generous, but after going through half of the chicken, it became a little tiresome and salty. Maybe more rice would help. 

Service is great and friendly, so no complains there. I can easily have a good meal and good conversation with the low noise levels and the prices are easy going on the wallet. I would come back to try other stuff, but the Chicken Kaarage is done a little strange for me.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Seriously, I Love this place.  It's run by like 3 old asian japanese ladies that pretty much would be consider your mom, aunt, and grandma all in one place.  The prices are very cheap for the decency of the food.  It had a great selection and there arent really any complaints about this place other than the occupancy of how many people can be in here at the same time.  Its a very tiny japanese place, and its very crowded on weekends and friday nights.  Reservations is pretty much necessary if you're going with a bigger group (4+).  The fish was fresh, and i couldn't be happier about finding this place.
author: Logan T.

description:
The salmon teriyaki is moist and delicious.  I am not a huge fan of the sushi, but I do love the dynamite roll, which has spicy tuna, hamachi, and avocado.  

This restaurant is actually owned and operated by Japanese people.  I always appreciate authenticity.  After coming here enough times and talking with the staff, I found out that the owner selects fresh fish and beef every day, so they can be from different vendors.  She picks whatever she feels is the best quality.  I like knowing that they put thought into the quality of their food.  It shows.  Also, they serve gen-mai, which I like so much better than regular green tea.  

If you are looking for an exciting culinary adventure and a wide selection of unusual sushi rolls, this is not your place.  If you are looking for high quality, flavor, and the simplicity that is a trademark of Japanese food, I think you should give Fujiyama-ya a try.
author: Kandi K.

description:
The service is super slow. It's a tiny restaurant so the wait to be seated can be very annoying especially because there is no real waiting area so if you're not the lucky three that can kind of fit inside the door.. Good luck waiting outside where it's usually really cold. Creepers from the bar next door might approach you too. Yuck. 

Food to me here is pretty standard for Japanese except the beef amiyaki which is sooooo goooood that it might be worth the wait and slow service. Maybe. Depends on my mood. 

Apparently they do take reservations though so call in next time so you don't wait an hour like I did.
author: A. Z.

description:
Love this place... food is authentic, fresh, and affordable... it's not one of those high-end pretentious places that charge ridiculous amounts for tiny rolls... this place serves generous portions (if you order a bento box)... in a cozy laid back atmosphere. 

My only warning... it may take a little while. Restaurant is small... and the kitchen is small... and it sometimes takes a while to get seated or to get your food... but it's well worth the wait! 

Try the beef amiyaki! It's amazing - and you'll be sad you didn't when you see the sizzling platter delivered to all the tables around you!!!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I've been going to Fujiyama-Ya for the past 3 years.  This place is everything you want a Japanese Restaurant to be.  It Also helps that little Esther, the woman that greets and serves you, is one of the nicest little women EVER.  

I'm allergic to uncooked seafood, so all that I can really comment on are the rolls that have cooked seafood, like shrimp and unagi and the cooked fish.  Which in all of the cases the food is delectable.  Their miso and salad are also very good.  Also, iIm a pescatarian, so I also can't comment on any meat dishes (sorry!)


There is just something about this place that always keeps me going back.  I actually held my 22nd birthday there with some of my family and friends.  Esther was nice enough to accommodate a group of 12 and all of my friends and family fell in love instantly.  I now have a couple of friends that every time they come and visit me, we have to go there for dinner.  

I think the only downfall about this place is that it doesn't open till 5:00pm every night, but that's ok cause it's definitely worth it!
author: Renae B.

description:
+ ambiance: the seating is very nice, and there are dividers for each section
+ affordable: spider crab appetizer, yellow tail roll, spicy scallops roll, caterpillar roll for $22 between two people.

- tea was watery
- speciality caterpillar roll made with too much rice
author: Anthony W.

description:
This place is EXTREMELY delicious! The price isn't too hefty, and the Sushi is always fresh. They deliver the order to you pretty quickly; service is definitely impeccable. 

The roll is my favorite, but honestly everything is great. I've had most of the Sushi rolls and the nigiri, and it's always as fresh as can be. Definitely come here!
author: Mike S.

description:
I went here for Dinner with my best friend last night. The place was small and we had a 10 minute wait at approximately 8:45pm. 
We ordered 3 rolls and waited a good 35 minutes for them..
The sushi were pretty tasteless.. and one was very very spicy.. we asked for some waters and the waitress acted as though she was doing us the biggest favor in the world for bringing the water over hahaha 
anyway we wont be coming back.. there are a lot better sushi places in san francisco!!!
author: Anya M.

description:
One of my new favorite Japanese restaurants in the city.  

The environment and food feels very homey, in a very good way.  

I loved every dish we ordered:  Soft shell crab, beef amiyaki, fried scallops.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I live down that block and never noticed this place...but it is actually pretty good... I ordered the Salmon Teriyaki with Tempura...really good Salmon and Tempura cooked perfectly. 

The service was really good and fast. I sat down and ordered and my food came out immediately. 

I will visit again
author: Brendan L.

description: This place is awesome.  The owner, Ester, is the sweetest little woman and will treat you like family if you are a cool customer.  Everything is good here and affordable.  Nigiri comes as one piece, which is fun if you want to try new things but not commit.  You can always find parking which is key.
author: Rachel W.

description: My family loves this authentic Japanese restaurant.  It's the way Japanese should be--simple and fresh.  There are so many dishes I love--beef yakiniku (sp?), dynamite rolls, salmon teriyaki, hamachi sashimi....We often bring guests there, and people always enjoy themselves.  Tip:  there is always a long wait (like 30 min), so don't come starving and expect to be seated right away.  This is a neighborhood gem.
author: Lizzie R.

description:
MMmmmMM! MmmmmmM! b*$#+!
After another 5 visits I just had to write an update!

I am now giving this place 5 stars! After today's feast, I've literally come to the conclusion this is my favorite Japanese spot in present day. 
I usually stick with Combination Sashimi here for 14 bucks, or The Saba Shioyaki for 8-9 Dollars. Then I order some nigiri here and there, while sipping joyously on hot sake.

The Ikura Nigiri here is to die for, I literally have fantasies about those fresh fish eggs bursting into my mouth just going through the day

Today, I figured I'd try something different, my gf got the Spicy Chicken(DELICIOUS!). I was picking off her plate, I'm embarassed! Then I tried the renowned Beef Amiyaki. SHE WAS PICKING OFF MY PLATE! 

I had no sleep  the night before my daytime shift. I hardly ate all day, I was starving, I must say I made the best decision coming back here tonight. We had such a satisfying meal, can't wait to go back!
author: Tip S.

description:
Got lucky and got a table when I arrived. The table next to the infamous "peeing man" picture also.

Beef amiyaki is still hands down the best thing here. It's still a must have here.

Also tried the crunchy sushi roll. The fish was fresh, but it wasn't really tasty. I guess it's try that they're not known for their sushi.

Sashimi plate's fish was alright. The price is good, but it wasn't great.
author: Steven B.

description:
Hubs and I were actually going for sushi, but when we walked in it smelled like delicious warm food, so we immediately changed directions. I ordered the chicken kara-age and the hubs ordered a beef donburi and we agreed to split a dynamite roll.

Pricing was great - our entrees were under $10 and came with miso soup and a salad, and the roll was also under $10, but looking at the whole menu, their standard rolls (like the Cali Roll) all loked like they were under $5 and more like $2 and $3!!!

Parking was not too bad since we came in at night and it's a commercial street so, except for the eateries, most of the daytime businesses were closed and left more room for eating patrons.

Mixed reviews on the food - The soup was actually also pretty good - not too salty and the salad dressing tasted like a sweet vidalia onion dressing.

I'm not a big fan of sweets on my savory dishes and when the hubs' donburi showed up, I immediately thought they might have brought him a different dish because it looked like beef teriyaki. No egg, and a thick brown sauce. When he tried it, he also said it tasted like teriyaki. When we asked the server, she said that they don't serve donburi (with the egg) with beef - just chicken... it would have been nice to know that BEFORE bringing our food in instead of the bait and switch (there are actually 2 separate menu items for beef teriyaki and beef donburi).

The dynamite roll actualy tasted really good, but the texture was excessively mushy. It's a bunch of minced fish (tuna and salmon, I think) rolled up with avocado slices and sprinkled with spicy sprinkles. I really liked the way it tasted, but it might have been a bit more texture-friendly with some cucumber instead of avocado (just a thought). I'd still order this dish - probably just with some other roll with a bit of crunch to break up the mush.

The kara-age was awesome. Kinda hard to go wrong with chicken nuggets (it's basically what that is, right?), but their batter was especially light and perfectly crunchy. It's worth mentioning that the flavor isn't really much of anything without the dipping sauce (tasted like ponzu) and rice.

Service was pretty good. Very friendly and attentive. She noticed that the hubs did not scarf down his food and when he got up to use the restroom, she cleaned up our table and asked me if he didn't like his dish. I noted to her that he was expecting the donburi with egg and not covered in teriyaki sauce. She apologized for his disappointment and finished bussing our table. I guess this means we'll just not order that dish again.

All in all decent spot for neighborhood eating and average food - nothing to complain about other than maybe setting better expectations on parts of the menu.
author: Kariz M.

description:
I would come back for just the spicy tuna (good and reasonable price).  I would skip everything else.


1) spicy tuna -good
2) california rolls (decent but not exceptional)
3)vegetable seafood dinner (bad - shrimp was tiny and bland, calamari was rubbery and also bland, mussel bad, mushroom and other vegetable was decent)
4) beef amiyaki dinner was just ok.  The sauce was too sweet for our taste
5)vegetable udon -decent, but not enough vegetable
author: L C.

description: Cannot believed I've never noticed this place before a friend brought me and the bf's family here for dinner. The bf and I have since come back for dinner too. Food is pretty cheap but pretty delicious. The rolls aren't rolled up very tightly but its not that bad. The beef amiyaki is definitely worth ordering just make sure you pull the beef off the sizzling platter as soon as it arrives if you like your beef cooked medium, otherwise it'll just keep cooking and get overcooked. Just wished I realized that earlier because the beef was so tender.
author: Sarah L.

description:
This restaurant is a childhood favorite. Growing up in San Francisco, my parents used to take me here all the time. Twenty years later, I still find myself frequenting this low key neighborhood sushi joint and recommending it to friends and family alike.

The place is fairly small, and when you first walk inside a wall of faded business cards greets you, followed by a sweet waitress named Esther. You hear classical music playing from a tape cassette in a boombox, see traditional brush paintings of Japanese warriors, and smell the savory aroma of green tea and lightly battered tempura. Instantly, you feel at peace.

The portions are huge and the prices are extremely reasonable. After 15 years, I still limit my orders to a few favorite menu items: the spider roll, alaska roll, salmon teriyaki, tempura, and beef amiyaki. I rarely eat red meat but their beef amiyaki is a hit in my book. It is a marinated USDA ribeye that comes to you in a sizzling platter, full of flavor and texture. I highly recommend enjoying this with their rice, which is premium quality Japanese rice, not plain ol' white rice. A bona fide sushi lover ought to be able to discern the two.

It really makes me happy that such a small establishment is able to remain in business for almost two decades as well as keep their prices affordable. The only reason I am not giving this place 5 stars is because I have only tried a few menu items. Overall, the food is fresh and tasty, the ambience is lovely, and it's definitely a great place to take a date or a few friends for a sake toast.
author: Patty L.

description: It's edible. I had the beef amiyaki people seem to be raving about, asked for it rare, got a dry piece of cardboard. Service was pretty slow, the place was packed for some reason, I guess I got a bad batch. The food seems pretty plain and straight forward, the prices are pretty good, maybe that's why its popular? Parking is pretty bad around here at times and it seems mostly for a place for sunset residents if you want good Japanese food go elsewhere.
author: Bruce W.

description:
Negi-hama: $2.60
Spider roll: $5.95
Cucumber salad: $ 1.95
Chicken wings: $4.25
Biting down on a fish bone AND avocado stem: PRICELESS!!

I was craving Japanese food after work but Goemon, Kitchen Kura, and Sozai were all closed. So I decided to come here and give this place a try. I noticed nothing on their menu was over $14. Wow! Hella cheap! But I had a feeling their cheap prices were too good to be true. 

Negi-hama is my favorite roll to order. Its hamachi kama with green onions. I like to order it everytime I go to a new Japanese restaurant. As I bit down on my negi-hama, I noticed something hard. I was like "What IS that?" Took it out my mouth and, lo and behold, its a fucking fishbone! WTF?! The workers did a HORRIBLE job de-boning that fish! They also did a half ass job cutting and presenting it!  Good thing I didn't swallow it! I would have choked on it ! And I'm glad I didn't chip a tooth or anything! It came with 6 pieces but I only ate 4. It wasn't that good anyway. The sushi rice wasn't even seasoned and the fish didn't taste that fresh.

Okay, now that I'm done with my negi-hama...I'm glad I still have my spider roll. Its hard to fuck up a spider roll. I mean,  the soft shell crab is fried up! What can go wrong? Well guess what? I bit down on a fucking avocado stem! Can't believe I bit down on something hard TWICE! Took it out of my mouth...looked at it...Oh Hell NO! This aint part of the soft shell crab! Its part of an avocado! Still can't believe that would happen twice! Why me?! Whyyyyyy???

So I flagged down the workers. 2 of them came to my table. I showed and told them  "I bit down on a fish bone. And I also bit down on this. It was in my spider roll. I think its part of an avocado stem or pit...." One of the ladies just giggled and said "I'm sorry." It was pretty busy that night and they both continued to go back to work. I guess they don't care about their customers? I was irritated. And yes, I stayed calm the whole time.  They're lucky I'm a nice person. If I wanted, I could have threatened to sue them or make a scene in front of all the customers. But I didn't. 

So I stopped eating BOTH of my rolls after finding my two surprises. I also ordered some chicken wings which took a while to come out. I thought to myself  "They better not fuck up my chicken wings! " Good thing they didnt. And I have to admit it was pretty tasty.  I mean, it would be impossible to mess up fried chicken! And as for my cucumber salad, eh, it wasn't that great. 

Okay, so the worker noticed I was done eating. Before she gave me my check, I asked her "Are you gonna charge me for these rolls?" She tells me "I have to ask." She comes back a few minutes later and says "I can only take off one." I told her "Okay, that's fine." So my check comes. I was expecting her to take off the spider roll (since it was more expensive)  but only took off the negi-hama. My $16 bill only went down to $13. WTH?! I was too tired from work to complain and just wanted to get the hell out of there. I didn't want to waste another minute my time or my server's time (since it was super busy) so I just paid my bill and left. I thanked her on my way out. 

In conclusion, cheap food usually means poor quality. If I were you, I would just come here for their cooked food. Don't even bother with the raw fish.

Btw, thanks for reading my  long ass review. You're awesome. =)
author: B B.

description: Fujiyama is definitely my favorite place. Cheap sushi and bangin beef amiyaki, I've never left this place unhappy.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
I have been eating here for decades, and it only gets better. The food is great, the sushi isn't the signature offering but it's very good. The best part about this restaurant is the food. The amiyaki is by far the best dish, but all the others are pretty impressive as well.

They recently added combination boxes to the menu and they are HUGE. They are very inexpensive considering the amount of food. 

Esther (the owner) is very friendly and her staff is very good at making sure your needs are met. I took off a star for wait time after ordering, and for overall experience when it gets busy. My intention isn't to downgrade their overall score and quality, but to forewarn future customers reading this, that when her place gets packed, it gets to be a bit of a wait...not more than 20mins mind you, just be ready to have some tea and talk with your partner. :) - When the food does come it's amazing. We love you Esther!
author: Edward P.

description:
So far one of the only places in the entire city to not disappoint us after a repeat visit is the simple and delicious Fujiyama-Ya.

The best thing on the menu is the beef amiyaki.  The sushi is about average, but it's really the cooked food that makes you come back.

We always order the beef amiyaki, tempura, and a sushi sampler (the tuna really isn't bad at all).

It's homie and a great meal, think of it as going to someones grandmas house for a japanese dinner.

A great place and if you go on a weekend night you'll need to wait in line.
author: Josh I.

description: Loved!! Great food, great service and great prices. I'll be back. Ps sunset sushi was the best!
author: Sarah C.

description:
3 stars just because my salmon skin roll was a little burnt and made it taste bitter.

I like this place because of the price thats right..... its a deal! Its hard being broke and loving sushi, especially salmon! the staff is the same as you get at any old Asian restaurant in the sunset, good intentions but the language barrier makes them come of as a bit rude. /:{ well to me anyway ( thats probably because i have bad luck with those things). Where was i oh yes the food is good and you have money left for desert !
author: Kristina S.

description:
I love this place and me and my family are basically regulars here. It has great food and is pretty cheap for what you can get.

Last night I came here with my parents to celebrate fathers day early. As usual everything was good and we couldn't finish it so it was packed up for us. We got home and a while later decided to finish it before it goes bad or whatnot. One piece of my dynamite roll ended up having 3 small round hard pieces of plastic. It definitely shocked me since I've never had any problems with their food. This really hits my trust hard and ill be more cautious making future returns less enjoyable but even so I'd definitely recommend this place. One small mistake is forgivable.
author: P T.

description:
I was taking my best friend on a sight seeing tour of the city, got hungry and yelped for sushi. found pretty good reviews about this place so we decided to check it out. 
We found it to be a cute 'hole-in-the-wall'. It was pretty small in size but small is good. The staff was very friendly and funny. Made my kids feel comfortable. 
The sushi was really YUM! My best friend and I have this thing for spicy food so we ordered the Crazy roll, Winter Wonderland, and i forgot the other roll but it was AMAZING! 
We didn't want to over do it by ordering more sushi so we had some of their ice cream.
