Loved it here and i'm glad that my best friend and i found this place. We will definitely come back for more!
author: Janine G.

description: I seriously don't know how this place gets 4 stars?! Really?  Tazaki on Judah has way better, fresher sushi than here. Came here yesterday evening with my hubby for dinner. We ordered the Chicken Udon- Chicken had no taste,yuck. Sashimi combo with rice underneath-Sashimi was mushy...is this how sushi supposed to taste? I don't think so! Was not fresh at all.  Finally, the spicy tuna roll- ehh, too much rice around a small amount of spicy tuna. Prices are fair, not over the top. But will not come again, back to Tazaki!
author: Alyce l.

description: My friend who lives near Fujiyama-Ya in the Sunset wanted to try this place since she had tried everywhere else on Noriega. Sadly the Japanese food was nothing special, and our waitress totally forgot about us. We tried it, and were not going back. I don't live near by so I didn't care if it was a hit or miss. But they really lost some local repeat business since my friend lives near by and would go back often if she liked a place.
author: Miss T.

description: Looks like a Japanese owned family restaurant. Service was alright. You really have to wave them down for service. They were giving orders to the wrong tables. Nigiris were affordable but lacking in quality. Charashi was below average; the rice was warm and only had 4 variety of sushi. We did get a free donut after our meal which was pretty awesome. Would not recommend but it's affordable. Suggestion: stick with the grilled stuff. The California roll was horrible.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
I came here with my friend just last week for the first time & I must say, it was not that bad for the price.

~Pro~
- VERY cheap
- friendly
- parking was alright
- awesome wall decor.
- quality of sushi is not bad
-clean
~Con~
- only opens for 5 hours (everyday 5pm-10pm)
- tiny place
- service was a bit slow (due to the massive amounts of 'take-out' orders)
- food took awhile to come out to the table

Overall, this place is pretty good! I would definitely come back again & again. Or maybe I'll get take-out!! =)
author: Selina L.

description:
My go to place for dinner or lunch when I don't want to cook.

It's an all woman crew and they work fast but be patient. 

My brother usually orders the udons which are definitely plentiful or the beef amiyaki in the sizzling platter. The meat is tender and marinated with great flavor. All the rolls are very cheap for what you get. Big rolls run you around $7 to $8 where small rolls are half the price. 

All around great experience here and I usually come here twice a month.
author: Wanster L.

description: Been going here for quite some time.  Family owned, very decent main stream Japanese food.  Price is pretty cheap, and quality is pretty good.  Beef Amiyaki (marinated rib eye steak) grilled is THAT good!  Very friendly.  Sitting is tight and gets pretty busy.  Service is slow, but they're so friendly that it's almost impossible to get annoyed.  Price versus quality and quantity if above average.
author: Joel M.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a little boy living on Noriega. I love this place. The food is great, the service is great, and the ambience can't be beat. Most of all, I love this place because they are always friendly and nice when you come in (and they remember me and my parents after all these years). 

I've never been disappointed with this place and have brought family and friends there on many occasions. The sushi is good and the price can't be matched. The sea food teriyaki is one of my favorites. 

I'll be coming here for many years to come.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Fujiyama-ya is my SPOT! I love it so much and literally eat here EVERY time I come home from college. First of all, its a smaller restaurant of about maybe 4 tables and 4 booths with only one waitress, Esther. Its a real quaint little hole in the wall type of restaurant without the dirtiness. 

The sushi is fairly cheap as makis can go up to $4, specialty rolls $8-$12 and nigiri $1.40 for one piece. combination boxes, chirashi and hamachi don are usually priced around 9.99. 

My favorite things to order are usually Beef amiyaki--comes out on a sizzling platter with a sweet teriyaki type sauce on a marinated, grilled piece of beef. YUUMMMY! Every time someone orders it, everyone watches it as it comes out because of the sweet sweet aroma and the sizzling crackles it makes. another one of my ultimate favs is the hamachi don--sushi rice in a ceramic bowl with about 12 slices of some of the freshest hamachi I have in the city. I'' usually orer a spicy tuna roll, rock n roll and some nigiri. My ULTIMATE fav however is the salad!!! I know, how great can a little side salad really be...? Well it's good enough that I order it EVERY time. Its usually served with allt he meals unless you solely order sushi. The dressing is similar to a sweet honey mustard type of base but a little japanese spin on it. Haha-- ok try and see for yourself, you wont regret it! 

All in all this is def one of my regular spots in SF as the food is SO AMAZING and the prices are even more amazing!
author: Lauren Y.

description:
What can i say about Fuji?

Well, I can say that I have been going there for the past 15 years.  This lil hot spot is only open at nights.  It has so much business that it doesn't need to be open for lunch.  The food is excellent!  BEST Soft Shell Crab in SF by far!

Here is what me and the buddies ALWAYS get when we're there:

- Soft Shell Crab (1 each)
- Oyster Tempura w/soft shell crab vinegar sauce
- Beef Amiyaki w/Hamachi combo or Shrimp Tempura combo
- Sashimi Dinner combo

All dinners come with Miso Soup, Salad, and Green Tea Ice Cream

Everytime I think of Fuji, I salivate like a Pitbull gone crazy!  Def one of the places that I'm addicted to.

For all the ppl that gave below 3 stars, you guys are ordering the wrong things!  ...and you guys call yourselves FOODIES!  *PATOOOEY!*

Thanx Esther!  You are the BEST!
author: Toma W.

description: My girlfriend and I have been going here for about two years since we moved to the area. Their prices are VERY reasonable compared to other Japanese restaurants with comparable menus/quality of food. The standard of quality when it come to the food is always above average and the taste is good. The portions are good, and are big if nothing else.
author: Sean Z.

description: Yum. The service here is good. It's usually not super busy. The food is reasonably priced for the portions. They did have a few vegetarian options, which I always like.
author: Crys L.

description:
This seems like a neighborhood local's joint. Everyone seems to know Ester.  

Food was okay. If you want your Japanese food fix, come here. 

I wouldn't say it's especially fresh but it satisfies the craving.  They give mediocre rice with the sushi ( I dont like it when they overstuff the sushi with rice). 

The rice wasn't too tangy/tart with rice vinegar.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Ahh...I concluded a great culinary day (thanks Yelp!) with some great sushi. This place is delicious & fresh. My girlfriend and I enjoyed lots of little dishes throughout the evening, the California roll w/real crab really stood out for me, but really everything was good. The inside was cozy, clean, and nicely decorated considering the small space they have. We waited a little bit for a table and they were out of Mochi ice cream, however the waitress didn't charge for one of our Green Tea ice creams since they were out. All and all a great little place.
author: Jeff S.

description: Whenever I'm home from Davis, this is the restaurant the bf and I will usually frequent. In fact, the bf loves this place SO much, he held his bday dinner here and we pretty much took up half the restaurant. The service is always great- the staff is polite and attentive. The beef amayaki is delish and a MUST TRY (as if the other reviews couldn't have stressed this enough) and I love their chirashi dinner combo. The fish is always tasty and fresh and I love that they add little bits of tamago and seaweed flakes to the rice. YUM.
author: Alice C.

description:
Some above-average tasting sushi. 
A wide variety of menu items to choose from
A little on the pricey side.
Will come back soon to try more stuff
author: Matt V.

description: This is my and my husbands go to sushi place. The sushi is simple and fresh and their tempura is delicious. It's a small place, so there is often a bit of a wait, but it's never too bad. The service is efficient and everyone who works their is very nice. I wish they had a few more rolls on the menu, but overall it's a great neighborhood spot!
author: Lana B.

description:
The place is small and the booths are worn, but there were plenty of people when we came in which is usually a good sign. Pleasant decorations are all over the walls, and the Japanese older lady working there seated us in one of the booths.

I had the House Special Bento Box which comes with miso and salad with a yummy dressing. The bento combination comes with gyoza, your choice of teriyaki - i got chicken- tempura and sashimi. This was a lot of food! The gyoza was my favorite :) The sashimi was tuna and although the slices were a little thin, it tasted pretty fresh. The tempura was decent, not terrible. There was one unidentifiable tempura thing mixed in with my veggies and which had a fishy taste and I just couldn't figure out what it was. I only took two bites, it tasted weird. 

My boyfriend ordered the Beef Udon. YUM! The noodles were soft and the broth was yummy! He let me have some noodles and some of his fish cake which I always enjoy :P 

We also had a Dynamite roll which had a really good spicy sauce on top, but the roll was kind of falling apart! It was tasty though. 

I'd come back here for some rolls and the udon!  \(^_^)/
author: Michelle R.

description: Mount Fuji Shop (as translated by my friend) is my only truly regular place in the city to dine. Why? Awesome value. Good food. Cozy ambience. Simple formula that has probably not changed since it opened. The service is consistently good - nothing remarkable, but always friendly and efficient. I have taken three sets of friends here for dinner and they have also become fans. It is always a treat to support a fun neighborhood restaurant where you feel like family.
author: Randy C.

description: Awesome Japanese in the sunset, dirt cheap, great quality, and even better service!
author: Robert V.

description: Was referred to this place by a family friend. Nice quaint little restaurant in the Sunset. We ordered the Beef Amiyaki and Chicken Karaage - both delicious choices and highly recommended! Their salad dressing is also yummy... Portion sizes are a little bit small, though. And since the restaurant is not that large, I recommend getting there early if you plan on dining in. All in all, a solid choice for Japanese cuisine!
author: Christine S.

description: much better than nearby Noriega teriyaki and at a better price. not great for groups though and seating can be a little too close for comfort, so i think of it as a cozy hidden gem to go to with close friends/family. maybe not the greatest or freshest sushi around, but for the price it really can't be beat. i would recommend any of the specialty rolls over the bentos/rice plates.
author: Cailin H.

description:
This is the Japanese restaurant that I frequent the most.  Especially if I'm craving sushi.  Their sushi is good and it's cheap.  I usually get my 3 favorite basic rolls here- the california roll ($2.85), the eel/avocado roll ($3.25) and the spicy tuna roll ($3.25).  Luckily for me, they make all 3 of these rolls very well.  Wow, did I mention that this place is cheap?  Where else can you get a spicy tuna roll for 3.25???  

It's not exactly world class sushi, but it's actually really good, and the price to quality ratio is terrific.  I really like the spicy tuna here. I've also tried the vegetable tempura and seaweed salad here and I have no complaints about either of those.  The one thing that I don't really like is their salmon rolls.  I don't like the taste of their salmon... for some reason, it tastes like smoked salmon to me, and I'm not a big fan of that.  I think I had their udon once a long time ago and I wasn't thrilled with that either, but it's been awhile so I don't remember it well.  

But if I want some good, cheap sushi, this is definitely the place to be.  I come here at least once or twice a month. It's that good!  It's sort of a hole in the wall and it gets crowded, so be prepared to wait for a table during dinnertime.
author: Tyler C.

description:
A small restaurant off of 19th and Noriega.    It didn't quite satisfy my sushi craving, but it quenched it a bit.  

the uni-sea urchin, the ika-squid, and the amaebi-sweet shrimp was quite good.  The hotate-scallop was so-so.  I think the quality of okay overall.   I did enjoy the Salmon lover's roll and the dragon roll.   

We sat in a booth, a little tight, especially with 2 kids under 2.  The servers were wonderfully attentive and courteous.    My friend and hubby had the bento boxes that had a lot of food.   

I had the chicken udon that became more chicken than udon after sharing with the 2 little ones.   It was fun watchin them slurp up their noodles!     okay, I think.   Would give it another try, but there are so many Japanese restaurants in this city.
author: Regi K.

description:
This place is really cheap. Like about $6-7 a roll (other places are like $9). Me and the bf shared a combo plate and two rolls.

TERRIYAKI BEEF W/ TEMPURA: This was a combo plate that included a small honey mustard salad. Although they gave a variety of tempura pieces (green bean, broccoli, potato, sweet potato, shrimp, and fish), it was ok...nothing special. The beef was good but a little to cooked for my taste but perfect for people who like their beef well done like my bf...can't really mess up this dish...just terriyaki sauce w/ grilled beef.

SALMON LOVER ROLL: the salmon tasted not as fresh...kind of bland...but it was decent for the price u pay. it was sashimi salmon on top of a california roll.

DRAGON ROLL: the didn't really enjoy this roll too much b/c they didn't de-bone it...there were a lot of tiny bones in the eel and it made it difficult to enjoy. 

My bf's mom got the seafood combo plate. didn't try it, but it looked really good. came sizzling hot in a skillet and it was filled with a huge variety of seafood. I'll probably come here again b/c it's really cheap and I'll try this dish next time. What ended the night really well....free green tea ice cream! my bf's family comes here a lot so they get free desserts! the staff here are super nice and very attentive. This place is really small, so prepare yourself for a wait...or just order to go :)
author: Ivy L.

description:
Ive been coming here for over 10 years now and yesterday was my first time back in many years. 
Side Salad - Very yummy, dressing has not changed 
Agedashi tofu - It was my first time having it here, and i felt like the batter was very stringy... the sauce wasnt that savory either
beef amiyagi - this use to be one of my favorite dishes here, however, it didnt taste like how it did 10 years ago.. Some how the beef didnt have much flavor, almost as if it's watered down?
All the sushi we had were okay, i've had better.... but i'll definitely be back for the salad :)
author: linda L.

description:
It's a quaint little restaurant that we've not visited in a couple of years but came to mind because Noriega Teriyaki down the street had a line in front of it and we were not interested in waiting for a table.  I was not happy with the food.  The crunchy roll was decent, with crab, tempura shrimp and lots of tobiko topping.  The hamachi nigiri was decent as well as the uni nigiri, which I rarely order.  My tempura was disappointing.  The batter looked crispy but tasted as if it had been cooked in rancid oil, the shrimp was surrounded on the inside with a pasty-tasting batter and the shrimp didn't taste fresh.  The vegts were very good with asparagus, broccoli, yam, potato and carrot.  The rice was sticky but didn't have that fresh fragrant smell.  I really didn't like the tempura dipping sauce which was overly sweet and unsavory.  I thought they used the wrong recipe.  

Hubby had the teriyaki chicken and Jr. Yelper the teriyaki chicken and beef.  The chicken had a nice BBQ flavor but Jr. Yelper complained that the sauce over the meats was gooey and sweet.  You would pick up a piece of the meat and see the goo hanging from it like mucus.   The salad served with the dinners was the highlight of the meal with crispy lettuce, tomato and a nice tasting dressing.  Prices were much cheaper than at Noriega Teriyaki with combos about $10 and my tempura was $8 and the nigiri was $1.40 for the hamachi (each) and $1.80 for the uni (ea).  Even so, I'll gladly pay more for better tasting food at NT.
author: Ry T.

description: Chicken katsu don, yum! And I'm not normally too keen on scrambled eggs on top of my food, but the rice bowl was delicious. Bf and I also ordered a caterpillar roll, rock n roll, and spicy tuna roll. With all 3 rolls, 2 miso soups, 1 salad, and the katsu don, the bill came out to only $23!! The waitresses are super sweet and as well.
author: Lily Z.

description:
One of my regular haunts on the neighborhood circuit. Out of all the non-fish dishes I've had here, the beef amiyaki, beef sukiyaki and the tonkatsu are the standouts. The sauce used for the beef/chicken teriyaki is a tad too sweet and syrupy for my taste.

The green roll (vegetarian roll with asparagus tempura) is great. The kappa maki is hit-or-miss.  They offer california rolls with either real or imitation crab meat.  Unfortunately, they mix mayonnaise in with the real crab.

It can get busy here during peak times, and Esther is the only one on the floor.  However, she's awesome so please be patient!
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Great deal on the food. Hot tea has actual leaves and muck; it is not bagged..

1 roll and a small side salad or something does the trick.

I liked how small and intimate it was! Does get crowded at the evening descends. A plus for accepting credit cards.
author: Pamela R.

description:
I shared a combo meal with my friend when I went with her family recently. We ordered the Salmon Teriyaki and Unagi combo. It was only about 16 dollars and I was extremely surprised and pleased with how much they gave us. There was a whole unagi eel and a big slice of salmon, they gave us two salads and two miso soups since they knew we were sharing and they gave us plenty of rice. It tasted amazing, they were both cooked perfectly and the Unagi came on a sizzling plate and with a good amount of unagi sauce. I'm definitely coming back here more often. 

My family has been going here since 20 years ago for about 17 years. We liked it so much that we went every couple weeks and the service was so sweet, especially Esther, she is the best! Then we took a break from sushi for a while and when we wanted sushi again we had found Kikis for take out but we only went there for the take out price with Lucky's coupons. I went back to Fujiyama-Ya recently with my best friend and her family and it was like nothing changed. Esther was still there serving us, everyone was so sweet, they actually remembered me from so many years ago. I haven't been there in a long time. Esther told me she still had our pictures and Christmas cards in the back of the store. My friends have a very special little brother who gets happy and excited while eating out and Esther knew exactly how to calm him, exactly what his picky little pallet likes and when to bring out his food.
author: Natalie K.

description: By far one of the best sushi places that i have been to! Its a great place to get a large amount of sushi for a small price!!!! If I could I would go there every day! Yeah its crowded there and it might take a while to get your food BUT its all worth it, and plus if you go with friends its a great time to spend your night with free amazing tea a miso soup! Stop hating people on the small sushi joints!
author: Nina M.

description: Small, welcoming restaurant. Their amiyaki is to die for! The servers are always friendly. Love the Miso soup and their veggie tempura. I try to come as soon as they open or I make a reservation ahead of time since there a limited amount of tables available.
author: Daisy V.

description:
This is my favorite Japanese restaurant. Ester and the food is what makes me come back here everytime .  It is so close to home too.
I'm not sure if the prices are still cheap. They finally raised their prices.
author: ramon L.

description:
On a hot day in April (Monday, 04/20/09, 90* weather in SF - no lie!), my grandmother and I were looking for a place to eat dinner on Noriega. Since it was unbearably hot, I suggested sushi (although I enjoy sushi in any weather)! My grandmother said that Fujiyama-Ya has a line out the door on weekends, so I assumed that the food was good. 

Although my experience wasn't "Yay! I'm a fan." worthy, it was definitely "A-OK." The complimentary miso soup was a pleasant surprise and my grandmother's order of chicken teriyaki was large and in charge.  The seaweed salad was standard, but, unfortunately, the unagi atop of my dragon roll was flavorless and soggy.

I doubt I would return, but many seem to love it! Fujiyama-Ya's food and/or ridiculously cheap prices must be doing something right!
author: Jaclyn T.

description: When I lived in this beautiful city, I used to come here pretty regularly, since I lived close by.  There used to be a man in his 50's or 60's who used to work here (maybe one of the owners?) who had a dry sense of humor, and I enjoyed the dining experience as much for his humor as the food.  I guess he's not there anymore.  We came in a few chilly nights ago, and the place was packed.  It is quite small--perhaps 10-12 tables.  One woman was waiting on all the tables by herself.  When I expressed that I felt bad for her, she said she was used to it.  Perhaps she is one of the owners, and therefore doesn't mind working that hard.  I ordered a dinner of sashimi and tempura, which included a small salad, miso soup, and rice.  The sashimi had a nice taste and the tempura was nice and crispy; not oily like some places.  My family and I really enjoyed the food and the ambiance of this small restaurant, and it was just one more reminder of how much I miss San Francisco in general and the epicurean delights to be had in the Sunset district!
author: Norm G.

description: One of my favorite places in SF! The beef amiyaki has no comparison. Their tonkatsu and spider roll are good too, but whenever I eat there, I will not miss out on the opportunity to order the beef amiyaki. It is a very small restaurant so going there with a big group is not ideal.
author: Wil P.

description:
Had an idea to have Japanese and ramen for dinner. I called in the order about 7.39pm and they said we could pick up in 20 minutes. I placed the order and my brother went to pick it up. The place was packed and people were waiting outside to be seated. This was at 8.00pm.

I had the caterpillar roll again. It was still good. Just like the last time I ordered it.
author: Jen C.

description: Sushi quality is ok, portion sizes are reasonable, albeit on the smaller side and the food is priced accordingly.  It is the best sushi place in the city or even in the Inner Sunset? Of course not, but it's fine and it's cheap for sushi. Service is good, but sometimes there's a bit of a wait.  I'll be back, but I'll never rave about it.
author: Matt B.

description:
Fujiyama-ya is our favorite restaurant! Esther is basically part of
Our extended family because we come Here so often! Our family has been going Here for over 10 years and the food only gets better! 
Everything you try will not be a disappointment and you will
Feel welcome and at home. 

Here are some of our favorites: start with the tuna poke appetizer, cucumber or seaweed salad or agedashi tofu if you want something warm. Then have yakiniku, or seafood, or beef teriyaki and sashimi dinner.. The sushi rolls are really good also! Try the dynamite roll if you like spicy food and  Alaska roll or negihama rolls. Sunset roll, crunchy roll, and salmon lover roll are more fancy and can be shared. 


You will keep coming back because of the warm hospitality and notice as you come back how this place attracts families-- and everyone knows and loves Esther. While the restaurant is casual we come here on weekdays, on weekends and for birthdays and family celebrations.

Everyone finds their favorites-- try it out you will not be disappointed. :)

** one more tip-- you can get any sushi roll as a hand roll if you are so inclined.

***last tip !  the food will not be hard even on a sensitive stomach -- my mom never eats out because of that reason and she loves it here! 

Parking !! Parking !! --- *** you can park at the chase bank parking lot across the street which is very convenient. ;)
author: Maria F.

description: We always go to Fujiyama-Ya for great Japanese food and even better service. We've been going to eat here for 7-8 years already and the owners/servers are friendly and accommodating. We have eaten there for several occasions like birthday and graduation celebrations and it's always a good time with good food. Although the location is small, it's always busy with satisfied customers.
author: David L.

description: I won't ever be back here again! The teriyaki sauce has a slimy texture it's like some blew their snot rockets in the sauce.
author: Daisy R.

description:
My first diamond in the rough! A lot of you might have missed this small little restaurant situated on Noriega between 19th and 20th. Keep your eyes open though because this place is a gem. I have no idea how long this place has been here, but I'm glad I got the chance to try it out tonight.

Food was delicious from the get-go. From the tasty salad with fresh greens and a delectable dressing to my scrumptious entree the beef amiyaki, the food was overall great. Some of the dishes we ordered:

Seaweed Salad
Gyoza- More than 6 pieces, cooked perfectly, nice skin and cheap
Agadashi tofu- A delicious, chewy membrane encasing the tofu
Alaska Roll- Good AND cheap
Rainbow Roll- Good AND cheap
Dynamite Roll- Good AND cheap
Donburi- Average, but large portions
Hamachi sashimi- Fresh AND cheap
Beef amiyaki- Heaven!

I just have to say again GET THE BEEF AMIYAKI. Apparently, it's their specialty. Served sizzling on an iron plate, it's tender, juicy, and just crazy delicious. All the food here looks to be priced at a bargain. It's not as cheap as Kitaro or Kiki, but it's better quality.

Only small complaint was the level of service here. The wait can get pretty long as there's only one lady working all the tables. I'm sure she means well and wants customer satisfaction, but her service skills could use a little polishing as well. Nothing to dwell on, though, as the food was fantastic and a deal. If you want to avoid the long lines and pricey menus at Okazu Ya, Koo, or Ebisu in the Sunset, come check this place out.
author: jeff c.

description:
Majority of maki rolls are less than $3.  Come on, you cant beat the price and the sushi... is pretty good.  There are times where the fish seems to be more fresh though then again there's other restaurants that seem to always have fresh fish.  

I probably gone here way too many times in one month already and i would go again.  I've become a regular in this small little place and the rolls are decent.
author: Mabel C.

description: My boyfriend and I must come here at least 3 times a month or get takeout. Our waitress Esther told us they've only increased their prices twice since the 80s. The sashimi is always fresh and the rolls are cheap (by SF standards). Love the coziness and the wait usually isn't that long, though the restaurant is pretty small.
author: Victor N.

description: I made a reservation for dinner for a group of 4, and upon arriving no one was present to greet the party. In addition, when I made the waitresses aware that my party had arrived they did not honor the reservation at all and still had myself and my party wait for a spot.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
THANKS YELPERS!
Ok so I went to this place after reading some reviews on my phone for Japanese places in the area I was at.  When I pulled up the review I knew right away where this place was. I brought my gf and our 2 kids, after sitting down I realized I hadn't been here in about 25 years!

I completely agree with Bret M. this place is great for what it is. If you want some fru fru fancy fusion Japanese iron chef food then keep moving along. If you want honest home style Japanese cooking (albeit with some American influence) at a bargain price than give this place a chance. I've been looking for an honest, flavorful Katsu donburi that wasn't $10! It bothers me to pay $10 for a simple (supposed to be inexpensive) dish like Katsu donburi. Though I've found a couple places that were about $8-$9 there were mostly bland.

Thank you Fujiyama-Ya for serving up a savory and generous sized Katsu donburi for $7.95. My gf ordered the Saba teriyaki, the fish was salty like my  mom/grandma would make and you get a whole half  with rice, miso soup and salad for...$7.95. My boy ordered Tempura udon, they allowed him to have all shrimp vs. mixed, for no extra charge unlike most places and they gave him 5 or 6 pieces...$6.95, my girl ordered beef udon, lots of meat, not the best broth I've had but it was good enough. I ordered a crunchy roll, it wasn't bad not outstanding but was inexpensive.

Bottom line, I will be back, the price is an extra bonus. Simple old/home style Japanese food at a bargain price to boot, domo arigato. (Mr. Robato : ) )
author: William S.

description:
Fairly easy to find parking, typically not crowded, and good location right off of 19th Ave make this spot a great place to go when the sushi-craving hits you. 

Very small and comfortable restaurant with some very cheap rolls. Not the greatest sushi in the world, but definitely good, filling, and cheap.
author: Justin B.

description:
It's hard writing a review for a restaurant that you've been going to ever since you were a kid.  For one thing, the quantity of visits certainly begins to outweigh whatever ideas or opinions you may have had at some point about quality.  But then again, if the food were really horrible, you wouldn't have been going back week in, week out for the past 15 years, would you?  

To be honest, the food here is mostly serviceable.  The sukiyaki is somewhat too sweet, as is their katsu-don.  Each time I have it, I find myself gulping down their green tea as I'd never enjoyed it before.  At least you can say they're consistent though.  For about 10 years straight, I'd order the chicken teriyaki, which in my opinion, is unbeatable.  But you're thinking, "It's chicken teriyaki...how hard can it be to mess that up?"  But really, their sauce is thick and tasty, their chicken never dry.

After trying most menu items though, I can safely say that their Beef Amiyaki is the best.  It is at once sweet and smoky, sizzlingly aromatic.  The beef, if you are able to lift it off the grill fast enough, is soft and tender, always begging to devoured.

Lately, since I've become more health conscious, I've only been ordering their chirashi and sashimi.  For a restaurant nestled in the Sunset, I have to understand that sometimes, their fish might not be the freshest...but what price comfort?  So what if the fish is sometimes frozen and the selection is somewhat limited?  What comes out is no more, no less than what you pay for.

I wouldn't in a million years give up the familiarity I have with this largely neighborhood establishment for the hipper and chicer sushi bars in Noe Valley or the god forsaken Marina.  What this place lacks in atmosphere, decor, and scene-ability, it makes up for in service, kindness, and downright charm.  I've known Esther for 15 years; she's seen me grow up from a fat kid with crooked teeth to a skinny 25 year old with crooked teeth.  And that kind of nourishment isn't found on just any menu.
author: Philip W.

description:
I'm addicted to: 

 . Small Dinner Salad . 
It may look small but it is so filling and the dressing is magical, I wish I could make it. But I don't know how so I keep coming here.

 . Spicy Tuna Roll .
 I don't know why, but these just taste way more flavorful, with just the right amount of "spicy" here than anywhere I've had  them.

 . Miso Soup .
 The best Miso Soup of my life.  I don't want to find a better one, this is so soothing.  I went to the downtown mall, ordered miso soup at lunch and it was so drastically different (like water with a drop of soy sauce), that I  to go to Fuji's for dinner, and drown myself in some Miso Soup done right.

The atmosphere is tight one, but it works with the type of place Fuji's is: that hole-in-the-wall TREASURE you almost hope no one knows about.  But trust me, the crowds are getting bigger every time we go, so ...somebody else knows how valuable that Miso Soup is!
author: Jen B.

description: This is my absolute favorite Japanese restaurant. Even though this place is slightly more pricer than other Japanese restaurants its well worth it. The food is good and the people who work here are nice and friendly. I would recommend the beef amayaki (marinaded steak) it comes to you in a sizzling hot plate. It is simply mouth watering good. Although it might leave your clothes splattered in hot oil and smelling like the steak, but i think it's well worth it. I usually get combo J because i love salmon. It's salmon teriyaki and sashimi (you can choose from tuna and salmon). I would also recommend the sukiyaki (vegetables and meat in a sweet broth) this place makes the best sukiyaki and it's only about 10$. Pour some soup into the Japanese rice they serve you it's so good. I love this place and i always come here with my friends and family. :)
author: Helen C.

description:
I've been coming here for years.  The food is consistently good, and they have a big sushi variety.  Try their Beef Amiyaki, which is like the beef teriyaki, but served on a flat iron plate. It definitely gives it that smokey grilled taste.  I also like their chicken kaarage and tempura.  Their batter isn't too think and doesn't dry our your mouth like other fried foods do.

Esther is the only server there.  She works everyday all night.  So the service can sometimes take awhile.  But she is very attentive when it isn't so busy which is understandable.
author: Cass J.

description:
Tried them 2x. 

Waitress did not understand Japanese.  Food wasn't bad, just didn't taste like anything.  Bland.
author: Dong T.

description:
Fujiyama-ya ME!

4 stars for quality & price (especially the price!)

This hole in the wall is not bad. I love my cheap eats and this place does not skimp just because the prices are low.  Prices are unbeatable--a Rock & Roll for $2.80, a Rainbow Roll for $6.95, Tempura for $5.95, Sukiyakis for $8. Their sushi menu is semi-extensive, with smaller, less complicated rolls--Makis range from $2-3, Special, more complicated rolls range from $4.95-$7.95 (extremely good deal for rolls!!--which are my fav!)  One roll to stay away from however is their Dynamite roll (spicy hamachi & maguro--came out mushy, and a bit stringy). For Sashimi, I'd stay away from the fish thats in the rolls. 

The place itself is not too shabby..it looks a bit on the old side, but does have some nice japanese decorations along with rice paper walls....cute and super cozy (its so small!) Full house on a Saturday night seats about 40 people max.

The waitresses are nice, but a bit slow..it took quite a while for our dishes to come out, and they don't come out all at once..which is a bit odd. Miso soup and salad are included with the meal though, which is always good. 

Overall, a meal for 3 people or 2 hungry fatasses, will be about $40...well worth it for all the food you get! Def gonna come back here next time I'm in S.F and want cheap but good sushi!
author: Jessica h.

description:
I've been to this place for a long time, 10+ years.
They are very friendly and attentive.
Price is very reasonable with excellent food.

Food suggestions;

1. Beef Amiyaki. Steak served in hot iron plate.
2. Beef Teriyaki. The meat is very tender.
3. Saba. Salty but good.
4. Salmon Teriyaki. 
5. Unagi Teriyaki. Very tender, served in hot iron plate.
author: Wid S.

description:
I love this place!! Their fish is fresh and tempura is soooo good. Price is very good for the quality of food. Its a small spot but definitely worth traveling out from the East Bay just to eat some Japanese. Thank you Ester!!

Note: Don't forget to check out the Japanese guy on the wall peeing. =p
author: MIKE D.

description: Been there a number of times over the last year. Never disappointed. The Amiyaki beef is a well seasoned steak on an iron platter, better than the traditional beef teriyaki. Better still for a few dollars more is the Amiyaki beef-termpura combination. Service is always good. The handicap accessible tables near the door can be drafty on a cold day when the automatic door opens, better seating would be in the back of the restaurant, or in the booths.
author: B C.

description: When I lived in the Sunset, Fujiyama-Ya and I were bffs. In one month, I ate there almost everyday. This place is good for the generic rolls for I never tried anything else. The prices here are amazing! Eating here for a month burned a hole in my pocket- most other sushi places it takes one or two times to burn a hole!  Haven't been here in a while, but would love to come again.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Service was slow.   And I mean SLLLLLOOOWWWW.  If I wasn't waiting for 1 hour photo processing at Walgreens I would have had a cow.  

The food was mediocre.  The soft shell crab in my spider roll was burnt cripsy.  Ugh.  I wolfed it down anyway since it took forever.  Hell, I was so hungry I would've eaten a napkin.  

Funny thing is that this was my 2nd time there.  First time wasn't that great.  Every place deserves another try.  In this case 3rd time's NOT the charm cuz' there isn't gonna be one!
author: Jeanne L.

description: All I can say is try the beef amiyaki and you will understand why you should come here. This one dish had me hooked and I usually come here every couple of weeks because I know this one dish is the best amiyaki I ever tasted. The spicy chicken is also a good dish. The rolls I've ordered here are very good, but the beef amiyaki is really what makes this place stand out. It is extremely good value for what you get. The miso soup/salad/tea is also superior compared to other Japanese restaurants.
author: robin b.

description: Love their Rib eye steak. Good atmosphere and nice and comfy/homie. What more can i say? The owners are very accommodating and their service is fast. I love this soft shell crab as well and their sushi is delicious. Another japanese staple restaurant to choose from.
author: A L.

description: Food is great ... Ester is one of a kind
author: Jessica P.

description:
3.75 stars.

Came here for dinner quite some time ago with a group of 4 friends. The place is small, so there was somewhat of a long wait. The food was good, and we ordered the sizzling beef dish (beef amiyaki); that was good. We also had sake and other sushi rolls. All were good, and the price wasn't that bad for the quality and portion. We were all full afterwards.

I would probably come back again.
author: Sam W.

description:
One of my family's favorite Japanese restaurants. This is a smaller restaurant but the food is good. They recently came out with an updated menu with prices a tad higher but still a good value. I like their bento boxes with a 2 item combo. They have a box for $14.95 with a choice of meat, gyoza, tempura, and sashimi. If you're really hungry - that bento is a good deal. My favorite combo items are the unagi (eel) with sashimi. I was given a bowl of salad, miso soup, unagi and sashimi (served on individual dishes). After having some sushi rolls - California roll, Catepillar, and Crunchy Roll - I was half full. By the time my entree came - I could only finish the sashimi. I like the freshness and texture of the sashimi and they were generous giving me 8 pieces. I also like the teryaki beef, chicken and salmon - the teryaki sauce is sweet like honey and light. You can't go wrong with what you're ordering. They have a really tasty sukiyaki broth that comes with shrimp, clear glass noodles, and other seafood. 

This place is good for cooked meals - not known for the sushi. I will come back again and again for the bento.
author: Candace F.

description:
A-OK is all I can give you Fujiyama it pains me to say because I can see so much potential it isn't even funny, but alas you get 3 stars only. 
Maybe it was the night or the fact that there is really only one server for this small place but the service was painfully slow. So slow that we waited and waited for our bill and my boyfriend had to finally ask for the third time and then walk up to the register and pay so we could get out of there before the clock struck 9pm!! 

Now that we have the service out of the way let's talk sushi. My boyfriend who has gotten wrangled into yelp picked this place based on its location (close to our home), prices and yelp reviews (I am such a proud girlfriend!!). I ordered a dinner salad, crunchy roll and spicy tuna roll and I have to tell you all 3 were fantastic! I was worried about the salad dressing because its honestly hit or miss, but this one was so tasty - it hit the spot. The spicy tuna roll was fresh and had a great finishing sauce that really made it kick and the crunchy roll was good as well. My boyfriend who has trouble keeping our order down to what we can eat also wanted to try the Gyoza which was not great - mushy and over cooked so much so that the veggies didn't have any taste, plus the sauce was super sweet and not complimenting to the dish. Since he is a veggie man he also ordered two rolls which were pickled to the point that the radish and squash were so salty they were not really editable. Sorta disappointing. He did order Udon as well and really enjoyed that and felt the soup had a good flavor. So a mixed bag overall. 

I think this place has potential but they need to retool some of their menu items and also get another server! She was sweet but overwhelmed and the people just kept coming. I think I will give this place another chance, but only one more and then it goes into my sushi bone yard!!
author: Heidi S.

description:
I like this place a lot. 

The decor and atmosphere is great. A little small, but comfortable.

The prices are very reasonable and the food is pretty darn good. 

The only thing I wasn't crazy about was the terriyaki sauce, it was a bit gooey. But the chicken was good. The tempura was Excellent! The California Rolls are ok. 

The service is great. And for a lower-end sushi joint, this places is right up there.
author: Chili B.

description: It was soooooooo Good! We had California rolls and tuna rolls, and pink salmon roll with spicy sauce, this last one was my fav! Tasty , great size and fullfiling. The lady that waited on us was really nice, friendly, and told us about this place, that have been around for years. We had a great time ! And we will b going back soon.great price for what you get!!
author: Karen P.

description:
This place is super tiny and comfy as hell. It would suck if this place ever got busy, but I doubt it ever does (EDIT: IT DOES!). Nice menu, covers my needs, nothing extensive.
The sushi is acceptable, a little warm and loose but it's not terrible and its CHEAP! Don't expect anything amazing from this place, but I can see myself going here regularly to get cheap sushi and some miso soup.
author: Serene L.

description:
This restaurants earns every one of it's 4 stars I'm giving it. Fujiyama-ya rocks in so many ways and here's why..

IT'S DIRT CHEAP.
I haven't been to a Japanese restaurant that can serves great food for such low prices. The Spicy Tuna Roll (6 pcs) is only around $3. The Dragon Roll (8 pcs) $7.95. The combo dinners are around $10.95 and come with miso soup, rice, and salad. How can you beat those  prices? You can't., really.

THE PORTIONS DON'T LEAVE YOU HUNGRY.
The salmon teriyaki was the most generous portion I've had. It wasn't thin like most places serve. It was thick, juicy, and cooked just right. I was also surprised to see fish as one of the tempura and not just broccoli, sweet potato, shrimp, and carrots. The dinners don't come with ice cream, but I was so full ice cream was the last thing i needed.

IT'S FAMILY OWNED AND RUN BY JAPANESE.
You won't find any hispanic sushi chef's in the kitchen or a bunch of young waitstaff trying to make a living. This place is great to take your family without the fancy plating and stiff ambiance. It's a small plce, but the seperate booths make it feel more private which is nice.

THE FOOD IS GOOD.
I know you might be skeptical about the food due to the low prices and don't set yourself up with unbelievably high expectations. The food is great for what the restaurant is. Trust. 


2 ROLLS & 3 DINNER COMBOS = $46 (excluding tip)

It's worth the few pennies you have to spend here.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Lived on Noriega street for the past 20 years and I just discovered Fujiyama. 

Clean, friendly staff and relatively quiet (compared to bustling Noriega Teriyaki). They're decor is more traditional with Japanese paintings and their booths give a cozy feel too. 

Their rolls aren't bad and reasonably priced. 

A nice local place to head out to for a "take it easy" kind of night.
author: P M.

description: This is my go to place for some late night Japanese food! They close at 10, that is an hour later then most sushi restaurants in the Sunset. I come here all the time with my friends and I highly recommend getting the BEEF AMIYAKI! Tender steak melts in your mouth, soooooo goooood! Entrees come with miso soup, salad, and all you can eat rice! Their sushi is really good and the price is not too damaging to your wallet. Esther and the crew are extremely friendly, most definitely makes your meal that more enjoyable.
author: Lex S.

description: Ok.... I did like this place. That is until my most recent visit this evening. I just found out that I am allergic to sesame seeds, so I have to be very careful. After I ordered I made sure to ask the waitress of there were any sesame seeds or oil in the rolls that I ordered. When she said no, I told her to make sure because I am allergic to them. Sounds like I got my bases covered, right? WRONG! After consuming a few rolls I notice some black seeds on my roll and promptly ask her why they are there. She takes my plate to the back, brings it back to me and says no, it's shichimi(which I later googled and found that it is made with sesame seeds). I asked her if she was absolutely sure, and wanted to believe her because I was so hungry that I really didn't want to wait for them to make my order over again. So here I am, hives and all, itching myself to sleep. Suck it Fugiyama-Ya!
author: Lily P.

description:
DH has been there so many times and he really love the place.  He told me there last Friday.  Japanese food in Bay Area usually either expensive or not good.  I persuaded my DH to have something else, especially that we need save money for our house-hunting plan.  But, he told me that I need to try Fujiyama and it's not that expensive.

DH is right and the food are good too.

Spider Roll "soft shell crab" ($5.95/8 pieces) - Not the best spider roll but the quality is what I pay, more than just worth to try with that cost.

Spicy Tuna Roll ($2.95/6 pieces) - I thought that I read the menu wrong or it would be small in size BUT it came with a normal sushi size and it tasted good.  I will definitely come back for this and possibly order it every time cos' I'm a spicy tuna roll fan!!!!

Unagi Roll (forget the exact price, likely $5.95/8 pieces, not sure) - good size of unagi and combination of avacado, the favorite item of my DH.  He can never eat enough if I don't stop him.  Of course, he will always leave some to me.  Thanks honey xxxxxx (oops, someone is watching, XD)

Chicken Kara-ge - just average as compared to the good sushi we have had.  Portion-wise, it is good enough for one with a big stomach.

Miso soup - average, I like it to have more tofu.  But, Fujiyama is very generous on the portion.

We have ordered one bottle of sake and the bill was $5X including tips.  It's a pretty nice dinner and HD said that he wanted to come back the next week!!!  This time, we may only order sushi and try some other different rolls.  See you later, Fujiyama-ya!
author: Roserrele W.

description:
i am a real big fan of hole in the wall places. why because they concentrate on good food and less on decorating the place. even though the place is pretty cool has decorated art work drawn onto the wall. 

parking is kind of easy but i went on a sunday. so parking was fairly easy. of course being in the sunset and the great city of san francisco parking is fairly hard if its busy in that area. 

the waitress that were working there gave us good service. even though toward the end of our meal we felt kindof rushed but i dont blame them since alot of people were coming in. because the place is fairly small. 

the price of the food is stupid cheap. but its really good. i ended up getting the beef sukiyaki and the shashimi appetizer. what alot of people dont know about sushi is what is good sushi? well heres the jist of it

fish itself has different grades. and its mainly hand picked. you cant just pick any kind and call it a good fish. it has to have a fair amount of fat on it and springy to the touch. ALSO a big clue if you know the sushi sucks is when you eat it. it has a very strong taste of seafood or fish flavor. which ISNT supposed to happen. that means the fish has been out TOO long or the fish itself isnt good. so be aware of that. BTW yeah the fish was fresh

all in all i highly recommend this place. if your looking for cheap eats but also authentic eats too.
author: Nicholas Y.

description:
We had the following for dinner 2 nights ago:

1. spicy tuna (good)
2. california roll (decent)
3. vegetable seafood dinner (bad - shrimp was tiny and bland, calamari was rubbery and also bland, mussel was horrid, mushroom and other vegetable was decent)
4. beef amiyaki dinner (aside from too much terriyaki sauce, it's ok.  We didn't know it was marinated in terriyaki sauce, it was too sweet for our taste)
5. vegetable udon (decent, but not enough vegetable)

Overall, we would go back for the sushi, but not for the dinners.  If we just had sushi, I would give it a four star, especially for the cheap prices there.
author: Tom S.

description:
The best soft shell crab I've had is at Fujiyama-Ya.

The panko breading is excellent and the crab is deep fried just right.  Plus the dipping sauce has that tangy kick that really brings the dish together.

For the main course, be sure to try the beef amiyaki.  The meat is sweet and succulent. Order the amiyaki medium rare because it will still be cooking on a hot iron skillet by the time it reaches your table.

The miso soup and side salad are tasty and they come with all dinner orders.  The chicken amiyaki and unagi dinners are also very good. As, for the sushi and the rest of the menu, I would say they are about average.

Also, you can combo your dinner order with an order of tempura or sashimi for a few dollars more.

Fujiyama-Ya definitely has that hole in the wall feel and Esther the waitress is extremely nice and brings that family type feel for your repeat visits.
author: Sam T.

description:
Very solid 4 stars Japanese.  I plan to return for cooked items but so far the sushi (numerous rolls) and good tempura appetizers have hit the spot.  I'd say the sushi is not quite as good as Yum Yum Fish Sushi's take-out but the slightly lower price combined with a cozy restaurant to eat it in by far makes up for any minor variation on quality or style.  Service was good and cheerful, I don't demand much or anything during my meal but the waitress was attentive and helpful to get down the orders and get the food out.   Really just an all around satisfying dinner out.  A hole in the wall I hope to visit again.

Update-- I came here again with a date and we had a ton of food-- sushi, tempura, edamame, wine and maybe more than I've forgot.  Very very good.  We sampled more expensive rolls since her work was paying :) and were very happy with the quality.  But still the bill overall was reasonable.
author: Shelley M.

description:
Went there on a Friday night with some friends, waited for about 10 minutes? not too bad for a Friday right?

My friends and I ordered the rock and roll, the dynamite roll, and also the dragon roll. Rolls come in decent sizes for great prices, ranging between $7 to $9. The dynamite roll was the best, the spicy sauce made it really good, I would order it again when I go back. 

We also ordered the Beef Amiyaki which was DELICIOUS! Juicy and tender; a must try! Chicken Kara Age wasn't all that great though, I felt like I was eating fried squid since it was a little oily. 

This place is good when you are just looking for cheap but decent japanese food, not my favorite, but I would go back again!
author: crystal w.

description: Some of the menu items are exceptionally cheap like the spicy tuna rolls and the oshidashi(hence my high rating), but otherwise the food here is mediocre. The waitress didn't tell us that one of our menu items no longer came with avocado, which saddened my sister and I. The restaurant is small and decorated festively, but I think I will stick to the other neighborhood sushi joints I know.
author: Netty L.

description:
I thought it was not bad.  The pricing was extremely decent.  A rainbow roll is only $9.00 and they sell their nigiri separately, so you can try all the different ones.  fish was fresh and the rice is good, but their sushi lacks something, or maybe it's the wasabi.  Small place, but service is decent.  
Spicy tuna roll was def. not what I expected, but good.  the spider roll disappointed me though b/c the inside stuff fell apart when I picked it up, so that's minus some points.  I will be back though, b/c I like the neighborhood and it's close to home.
author: AhLin C.

description:
for reals. this is my secret hole-in-the-wall japanese place.

it's 1 block from my house and extremely affordable, but this place has more to offer than distance and low prices.

the food is good!

apparently all the other reviews note the low prices so it's not my distorted reality field acting up again.  i go here, eat drink and be merry, then walk out with a few dollars still in my pocket.
author: Ameer N.

description: My husband and dghtr and I are regulars, usually eating here about twice a month. Normally I always order the gyoza dinner or if I am extra hungry, a bento. The other night, because of some dental work, I decided I had to order something easy to eat. I settled, reluctantly, for the udon with tempura, assuming the tempura would be mushy from soaking in the broth. Such a nice surprise after the dentist: the tempura (2 shrimp, lump of fish, string bean, carrot slices, potato) came separately, which allowed me to soften the tempura to suit my needs. The broth was excellent. All this plus soup was less than $8.00!
author: G B.

description: i ordered to go but it was good. i got the Philadelphia Roll, scallop roll, and some others i forgot. i would come back here again in the future.
author: Linda A.

description:
Fujiyama-Ya was a huge disappointment.  The soft-shell crab had a slightly burnt, heavy crust, more like what you would find a tourist seafood shop than a good Japanese restaurant.  I was looking for the tartar sauce.

The sushi and sashimi was presented artlessly, a real oddity for a "Japanese" restaurant (I'm pretty sure they are Chinese or Korean), the rolls were amateurish, and some of the fish wasn't fresh enough for raw eating.  In particular, the salmon had an over-the-hill flavor - it would have been acceptable for teriyaki, but not for sashimi.  Decent supermarket sushi is as good as this.

We regretted not going to K's Kitchen, which is closer to home.
author: Spike S.

description:
I understand it was mother's day, but c'mooooon 1 hour to get our appetizer? we ordered at 8:50pm (when the bulk of the crowd was gone) and got it at 9:50pm.  We all ordered the amiyaki (ribeye steak) and my sister got the udon. Our dinner came out about a few minutes after the appetizer and we had to ask for my sister's udon twice after that. I know that sounds harsh, but c'mon...... they didnt even apologize to my sister.  

the food was good, hence the 3 stars, but the service was not so great.
author: kim l.

description:
This place has been here for a longggggggggg time, but my family always decided to skip this place. 

It looks pretty janky from the outside.

We've tried every other place on this block and the next, and finally one day, RECENTLY like a year ago, my brother took us here.

My mom fell in love, after that, we came here almost 4 times a month..plus its close to our house.

But anyway, GET THE bee amiyaki. you wont regret it. If you like your meat raw, take it off the sizzling plate when they give it to you!!

I feel kinda bad for the old lady server here, sometimes she's the only waitress/server/cashier person, and it gets REALLY hectic in there.  A lot of times, she forgets your drink, or a roll you ordered, AND EVEN NOT CHARGE YOU FOR THINGS YOU ORDERED.......... :D
author: kim w.

description:
This is as good as I've had in San Francisco so far.  Taken by a local, we waited for seating, but it was worth it.  The rolls, terriyaki, sashimi and even the tempura was better than just good.  

I will admit, the warm sake probably made the whole experience just that much better, but I still thing this is a good bet for some great Japanese fare, and when I go back, I'll have no problem ordering something I've never tried before.  I think that's the true mark of a good restaurant - you trust them with all menu items!
author: Shirley L.

description: There are at least 3 other Japanese restaurants in the area but we only go to them if Fujiyama-ya isn't open. Our favorites are the sushi deluxe platter, tempura, chicken teriyaki, California roll,  green roll, and gyoza. Vegetarian friendly with veggie gyoza as well as several tasty vegetarian rolls.
author: Md G.

description: The sushi is decent here. The pricing is also decent to borderline expensive for what you get. The wait staff is very kind. Cozy but small dining area is okay.
author: Keit K.

description:
I came here to specifically try the beef amiyaki.  The first few pieces were good, but as they cooled, the meat became tough.  Must be that the beef got overcooked as it sat on the iron plate.

Gyoza was good, California roll average, and the chicken terriyaki was down right unappetizing.   The best item was the unagi on an iron plate.  Melt in your mouth good, but watch out for little bones!  The salad dressing was second best - I like touch on the mayo and hint of sesame flavor.

The portions are good and this is good value if you are in the mood for average Japanese food and want to get filled up.
author: D C.

description:
id go here more often if it was in my neck of the city...

the lone waitress is esther and she is super sweet and does a great job running the front all by herself.

salmon teriyaki & chicken teriyaki is the BEST ive had in the city. 

california maki roll is super cheap AND good.

tempura roll is super cheap AND good, also.

good stuff kids, good stuff.
author: kim f.

description: Been going here since I moved to the city a couple years back. Two can fill their bellies on tasty rolls, seaweed salad complimentary miso, have a beer and get outa there spending less than $50. Without a doubt, my favorite sushi place in town.
author: Brian B.

description: I love Japanese food. I wasn't really expecting a phenomenal dinner when I came here with my friends so I wasn't really disappointed with my meal. One of the things that I disliked about the decor was the booth. Sitting in a booth with five people was crowded and my back was pretty uncomfortable throughout our whole meal. I ordered two sushi rolls because I needed my fix of raw fish. I could tell that the salmon wasn't fresh, it was kind of tough and looked funny. The white rice that was served with my friend's bento box was super sticky which is not tasty. I liked the fact that it's cheap, but I won't be returning to this place anytime soon.
author: Lauren L.

description: This is a very homey place...its mom and pop and they are real nice. It has a good feal to it becuase it feels like you actually eating in a little store in Japan. The food is excellent and I just love the potstickers and dragon rolls! The T-Steak is good too. I order sapporo with some saki and it does the job....this is a perfect little place to a casual date or when you'd like to go with good friends for some sushi!
author: Eric S.

description: You get what you pay for.  The sushi here is cheaper than taking the manatee to jack in the box.  Manatee always somehow eat $20 worth of jack in the box after lying around doing nothing all day.  The spider roll was like $6 but its a wimpy excuse for a spider roll.  The crab is small and dry.  The other sushi rolls here aren't bad.  Definitely worth the price.  The beef amiyaki for $12 is a steal.  A thin piece of rib eye for $12 is pretty good.  This place is a good place to go for cheap Japanese food.  The sushi is better quality than Kitaro in the Richmond which is not hard to beat.  The manatee had salmon sashimi with salmon teriyaki for around $11.  Ridiculously cheap and it was pretty good.  Fat people should unite here.
author: Fatty A.

description: Esther is the BEST! Nice service, cozy envioronment and decent food at a great price!
author: L W.

description:
We have been there about 10 times in the past year. Very reasonable prices, and delicious food. 
We keep coming back.
author: chad k.

description: Wonderful food, friendly host, very reasonable prices, and a great atmosphere. What more can you ask for? It's a hidden little gem. I make sure to take all of my friends here.
author: Curious B.

description: i tried this place because it was close and the food is not all that great. the prices are ok but would i ever come back most likely not. The sushi is just way to plain no taste really. i guess it would ok for people who are craving sushi but are on a really tight budget. I would rather pay more for something that taste much more authentic.
author: Art N.

description: I've been here a few times and it's becoming one of my favorite sushi places in the city.  It's not a really fancy restaurant but it's my go to place for a quick sushi x bento fix.  Quality is decent and portions are good for the price.
author: JACOB L.

description: Cheap sushi rolls and tempura is just perfect!   Love coming here on cold days-finishing up meals with HOT sake!
author: Tessa M.

description: Compact place; maximum capacity 40. Long lines on Fridays. Slow service. Only come here if you have 3 hours of your life to waste.
author: Keiko C.

description:
This was not a good sushi place.  I ordered the salmon sashimi, and I was wondering why it was cut so weird... I had never seen a sushi place cut their salmon into such inelegant chunks before.  It was as if they were going to feed their cat with this, and gave it to me at the last second when I placed the order.  Not that I really care about presentation that much (I'm not a judge on Iron Chef, for crying out loud), but I should have realized this was the tip off that this place sucked.  The fish was horrible, and tasted both fishy and rubbery.  I took one bite and left the rest of the order on the table.  Thank God I didn't get gastrointestinal distress or worse from that.

As well, the gyoza was bad.  Man, if you can't even get THAT right, there's something wrong.  There really is no excuse for having such below average gyoza.  Here some advice to Japanese restaurants:  If you're really desperate for gyoza, just go to Costco and buy a bag of Ling Ling potstickers... boil, fry in frying pan with lots of vegetable oil, and pass them off as gyoza.  YOU NO LONGER HAVE ANY EXCUSE FOR TERRIBLE GYOZA!!!
author: Stan L.

description: The beef amiyaki is definitely my favorite Japanese comfort food.  I never leave disappointed.  This used to be my favorite restaurant to go to after a long day of work, unfortunately I come here a lot less now.  The owner is always really pleasant and she makes an effort to remember everyone.  Definitely recommend this place for some good Japanese comfort food.
author: Jen L.

description:
One of my fave restaurant. It's not a fancy restaurant but it's a family restaurant that makes you feel comfortable. The price is just right and the food is pretty good. 

I love the spicy tuna rolls, spider, caterpilar, dragon rolls, etc.. The salad is the best i've ever had. Try the beef amiyaki or the beef teriyaki, it's very good.
author: sofie W.

description: This place was my first stop as a new resident of the Sunset, and I'm stoked. The sushi was solid- not the best ever, but tasty. The fish seemed to be very fresh, which is the most important thing to me, I thought there was too much rice in the rolls, and the rice looked like they use long grain, and not short grain, which is usually what's used in sushi. I was also happy to see a lot of people in there. The service was kinda slow.
author: Michelle M.

description: not bad. their sushi didnt look like they were made very neatly but at least everything tasted good. i need to try that beef dish everyone raves about... next time!
author: Gordon L.

description: Fujiyama-ya is right around the corner from our place, and has become a weeknight favorite on a regular basis- and not just because of the convenience.  Their food is fresh and well-crafted (the beef amiyaki- as others have noted- is amazing, and their dragon/spider/tiger rolls are to die for), the price is astoundingly affordable, and the service is impeccable.   Tell Esther I sent ya- she's a total sweetheart.
author: Scott F.

description:
Really? A four-star average for this place? 

This place looks authentic, smells authentic, yet tastes unauthentic.  I could've sworn the place was THE BOMB five years ago.  Either (1) My tastes have improved, or (2) Their quality has deteriorated.  Or both.  

The menu is mediocre - contains your typical teriyaki / tempura / yakiniku / tonkatsu / sushi / sashimi.  Randomly chose beef amiyaki because of its funky name and the fact that I haven't seen it elsewhere.  

The beef amiyaki (grilled beef marinated in mildly sweet soy sauce served on a hot plate) was delicious (albeit a bit fatty), and their rolls were tasty and the sushi chef was generous with the fillings.    

The salmon sashimi, though, was just about the worst that I've had - huge contrast from the melt-in-your-mouth variety that we got from Tanto (see my other review).  

The price tag is probably just about the best thing about this place.  $2.95 for a big fat spicy tuna roll, $5.95 for volcano roll that could easily cost $10 elsewhere.  

Later on we realized - this place is operated by Koreans.  That explains the awesome beef dish and the mediocre everything else.

A rather underwhelming start to a weekend... but anyway.
author: Ange L.

description: Let me start off this way... we waited for a very long time on a sunday night. We got here at 7:15 and we left at 8:30pm. It wasn't crowded, the problem is that they only had one waitress. I have to say she did an excellent job with what hand that she was dealt with. We waited and waited and waited for food and drink to come but we understood the lions den that we waltzed into so no surprises. We finally got our food around 7:50 and boy was it worth the wait. I ordered a Dynamite Roll and a Rainbow Roll and the wife had the Beef Donburi. The sushi was very good and grade A quality and lots of it on the plate. But the real winner to me was the Beef Donburi. Something as simple and as boring as this dish was the kind of cut of meat that they used was well worth the 7.50. I fully expected thin little mitre saw cuts of beef cooked so long that you could slap a person with it and it would draw a tear. But no.... this meat was tender and thick cubes over rice and drenched in teriyaki sauce. I'm going to have to come back to try another type of sushi roll but I highly recommend it but you may want to do Take out....BTW if you open the door and it stays open, it's an automatically closing door. So don't tug you'll just draw stares from the regulars like I did because i couldn't understand what the hell was wrong with this thing then i read the sign and had to take a breather outside. Read the signs, no wonder why people get into car accidents, read the signs. hopefully i could save your hyde from being embarrassed like i did.
author: graham c.

description:
i thought i'd give this place another try.

this time i had not only their dynamite(?) roll, but also a hamachi sashimi platter...


HAD TO CUT THE DINNER SHORT. immediately, LITERALLY after my last bite of sashimi i had the RUNS!
author: Rosalee C.

description: This is a nice cozy Japanese restaurant.  Though its small it wasn't too crowded but there were still a few people eating....I got there around 8...I imagine there would be a wait on weekends....  The lady working there is super cool too.  Found parking right in front so it was a short cold walk...the Sunset is freakin cold!....Got the beef amiyaki and a nice warm soup....didn't end up trying the sushi here...maybe some rolls next time with the amiyaki....I should mention the place is clean too and they take credit card! Big ups for that!
author: Summit S.

description: This place is right up the street from me, which is super convienant! I went there with 2 other people and we ate until we were full for only $24 total! On top of that the sushi was really good. Rolls for only $2.50? Plus, I got two bowls of  really good miso soup for free, plus free tea.  The woman that served us was  really nice and down to earth. The seaweed salad was some of the best I have tasted for a while. The setting was small and cozy which I loved as well.  Definately worth a visit, it's my new favorite sushi place!
author: Sonya D.

description:
I like this place. It's my 2nd favorite Japanese place (Fuji will always being first in my heart). The lady who serves is so nice and she always remembers me, my husband and our baby (now a toddler). We've been going here for almost two years and never had a bad meal. 
I usually order the salmon teriyaki and while you can tell the fish is not as high quality as what you'd get (for double the price) at Fuji, it's still delicious and the teriyaki sauce is so tasty! I also love that unlike other Japanese places I've been to, they give you a generous ladle of sauce - they don't skimp. Love it!
The chicken katsu is the best I've tried - they use breast instead of thighs, which I definitely prefer.
My husband likes the chicken donburi (I didn't care for it). 
The only thing I've tried here that I really thought was bad was the oshidashi, which was way too sweet for my taste.
The food isn't spectacular, five star food, but it's good, almost home-cooked feeling food and always comforting. And like another reviewer said - lots of kindness all around. I've never had an impatient or unkind attitude from the woman who works here and we've been there on some extremely busy nights where lesser people would have been downright rude.
So - whenever we're in the mood for Japanese food at a good price, this is where we go. Warning though - don't go on a Saturday night - Sundays are touch and go too if you go after 7. You might wait a long time!
But weeknights, and Sundays before 7 - yummy, comfort Japanese food.
Yay Fujiyama-Ya. Now I'm craving salmon teriyaki.
author: Laura G.

description: I had high expectations for this restaurant from the yelp reviews and from the impression I got when we first arrived. The place is cozy which gives a feel of authenticity. When we walked in, it took a while for someone to attend to us. Overall though, the service is very good. We got the back booth which was very private and nice. The prices on the menu are really cheap. I search far and wide for delicious sashimi combos and chirashi. The next time I see 16 pieces of sashimi for $13.95, I'll be sure to rethink ordering it. Reading the menu got me really excited because everything looked good and was really reasonably priced. However, when the food came out, it was just mediocre. The best thing was the grilled unagi. I like that they give the table a container of rice to share (like a chinese restaurant) so you don't have to order individual bowls. I had the sashimi combo and the fish was NOT fresh. It was mushy. The tempura is also overly battered. I left over half of my sashimi and the waitress asked if there was something wrong with it. I didn't want to be rude, so just said it was too much. But she asked again with a genuine concern, so I told her that it wasn't that fresh. She ended up giving us $5 in cash (as a discount on the sashimi) when she gave us our credit card back, but we refused to take the $5. I appreciate the restaurant's effort to serve a variety of Japanese food at a reasonable price. I don't know if I'll ever come back, but if I do, I won't order any of the raw fish.
author: June Q.

description: I'd give them five stars if the waitress didn't hold back on the sake, but she's a real sweetie.  Everything is cheap and fresh their beef amanyaki is my favorite but my Japanese obsessed friends rave about their hand roll.  I've started taking it to go and eating it at the Eagle next door where the drinks pour heavily.
author: Kris J.

description: Great place for dinner. Really friendly staff. I try to eat something new every time I come here, but I usually end up getting the salmon teriyaki. The rolls are priced fairly well and you get miso soup and salad with pretty much every dinner.
author: Jan C F.

description:
I come to this restaurant ALL the TIME!  This is the most worth it Americanized - Japanese restaurant.  They have fresh raw fish, I just don't eat it.  Their ingredients are fresh and their overall quality is pretty high compared to other Japanese restaurants in the area.  
I always order their Catepillar Roll and they NEVER disappoint.  Good flavor, presentation, and price.  I always compare prices with other restaurants and this place charges like 7.95 a roll compared to other places that charge 9.95 or 10.50.  If you know a place that can compare to that price and quality...LET ME KNOW because this place is the place I'd buy my catepillar roll.  I do buy it in other restaurants, but it's always with a slight hesitation because the price just can't beat the prices at this restaurant.
As for coming here a lot, when it was my birthday, I went to this restaurant 3 times within the span of 10 days.  It was a good birthday...I like to order Seafood Nabeyaki (very good broth), Chicken Amiyaki, and Unagi Donburi.  Those are my basic go to entrees at this restaurant and it's SOOO GOOD...

4.5 stars!  =D
author: LovesToEat S.

description: What isn't there to like about this place? Since i moved in over on taraval I've eaten here almost twice a week! The quality to price ratio really cannot be beat. I am always hesitant to go anywhere else but here. I usually eat dinner fairly early so waiting is never an issue. And the older woman that usually runs the place is the best! I always forget to ask her name but she's extremely proficient and a total sweetheart. I will eat here til the day i die!
author: dylan p.

description: Mmmm.  Excellent inexpensive sushi in an unassuming locale. Never would have found it if it weren't for a friend's girlfriend, so thanks, Patty!  I had a variety of maki and nigiri as well as the hearty miso soup and cucumber salad.  Several friends ordered the beef amiyaki and swear by it.  Everything I had was fresh and crisp, and the plum wine was perfect, too. Easy to park, and no wait inside.
author: Jude F.

description: Small little restaurant with big hearty food. their rolls are yummy and the fish is fresh most of the time. most of my friends go there for the beef or chicken amiyaki but i've recently opted for the salmon teriyaki. which is pretty good and nicely portion. always a nice place to eat with friends.
author: Rhonda H.

description: My favorite Japanese restaurant in the area - love the combo (any 2 entries) dinner.
author: Ranger A.

description: When you come in the door, the seating is fairly modest. It isn't a large place, but it seems like a good place to bring a friend or two. They bring you hot tea, which was great because it was such a cold day. Overall, I'd say everything turned out fine. But I probably won't be going back here. It wasn't too different from most of the japanese restaurants I've been to before. I usually like japanese restaurants that serve things other than the usual tempura and sashimi.
author: Kay T.

description: I've been here about twice. It is a pretty small place and they have interesting pieces of art on their walls. This is my favorite place for Chirashi because of their $11.95 price. Their sushi rice in the chirashi has little bits of tamago (sweet egg omelette) and nori (dried seaweed) which I think is an enjoyable little perk. Donburi here is reasonable and decent too although it does not come with egg as I am traditionally used to seeing. Sushi rolls and Sashimi pricing are pretty cheap and everything came out good. I am definitely going to stop by more often when I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Tracy N.

description: To me this is as close as it get to my mom cooking for me (at least in this country).  My friends and I have never had a bad thing here.  It is real comfort food to me.  The beef amiyaki and the sukiyaki are my faves!
author: Loren H.

description: This place is the best affordable Japanese spot in town..highly reccomended..
author: Asia S.

description: I love the small family restaurant atmosphere. It keeps the prices down and the food authentic. I ordered the pink salmon roll and a salmon skin hand roll. It took the kitchen forever to make the food. I think they serve one table at a time. The salmon skin would have been better if they put some sauce to make it juicier. The sashimi is pretty worth it. For a side, you get 7 pieces for 8 bucks. The yellow tail was good, but the salmon quality was lame. Overall, a good place to go for a cheap slow meal.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The food is good and the prices are great for Japanese food. This is my second time coming here, and probably not the last. The first time was super busy, so the waitress kept forgetting about certain things (like a whole caterpillar roll!). It's ok though, she was the only one working and it was hectic. 

The second time was more pleasant. Between us two girls, we ordered a combo dinner (beef teriyaki, tempura, rice, and salad) to share, crunchy roll, and spicy tuna roll.
